content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Tesla Effect: A Tex Murphy Adventure is a Point & Click detective film noir FMV adventure game. Waking up with the past 7 years as a gap in your memory, you set out to put the pieces together of who you became during those years, and find out why you lost your memory.Pros: This is a new sequel to well beloved FMV franchise of the 90s. All recurring characters, 8 of which I can think of, are played by the same actors as those who left us off in Under a Killing Moon, Pandora Directives and Overseer, which is quite an accomplishment 16 years later, although only 7 years have passed in-game. The memory blank allows players of the previous games to jump right in where they remember the story, which is where Tex remembers it. Jokes are corny but Tex's smirk remarks are always worth a smile, giggle, or even laugh. The game has 4 different endings, and even branching path as entire levels could only be played with certain paths, like the Sewers, the Blue Dragon, and many flashbacks. There are many Easter eggs of clips from past games of the franchise, as well as many locations where points can be gathered by looking at the many portraits of Kickstarter backers on the walls (every single one of them with a personal one-liner from Tex!).Cons: In the first person perspective, the textures are awful, and I mean it. Any FPS players will be turned off by the game's graphics, and is obviously not where the attention was put. The game is somewhat short for an adventure game, and you don't feel as much as a P.I. as you did in previous games and barely spend any time in your office, or getting "cases" from clients. Money and shopping were completely removed from the game. The puzzles were for the most part easy, while the conversation options that define how your story will unfold are utterly vague, often misleading.Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to youHeck, I had fun playing this game! There is no doubt everything that did carry over from the franchise was an improvement over previous games. Some things could be better for sure, but the game's heart is in the right place: a homage to an underrated FMV franchise that should've been remembered as one of the best of its time, and it's great to have one more go at it. FMV as a whole might not make a comeback, but Tex Murphy is welcomed to do so!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												NOTE!!!:  I've played this game 3 times through!  Steam only counts online play, I've played mine while offline.Funny story driven detective game.  That's this game in a nut shell but it's so much more.  If you have played the previous Tex games, this is a must have game since it will fill you with nostolga and you will fully appreciate the occasional "inside jokes"  If you are new to the Tex universe, this game stands well on it's own as it explains enough of the previous games(back story) so you know exactly whats going on at all times. If you like games that are story driven, like comedy, and figuring out clues in detective style game play...  This game is for you.If you're the type of person that fast forwards past the dialog in your games so you can get back to the action, hate small puzzles (not jigsaw, all types), or has to have cutting edge graphics in your game (FMV scenes are cutting edge, it's the 3D enviornment you navigate around in the game that are about 10+ years dated) .....then this game is not for you.Graphics:    Full motion video : 10  ---   3D environment: 6--Two scores here, FMV is awesome, the 3D is meh but it does get the job done.Sound:  9--- Awesome music and voice work, they should sell the music it's so good.Controls:  7--- The controls are nothing new or special and any person who has played a 3D game will jump right in.  Other than ladders seeming a bit aquard to climb, all other motion contols work fine with no glitches or getting stuck.Replay: 6---  This game has 5 different endings and the 3 different paths you can take have a unique location(s) to them which increases replay value but once you beat all five endings, the replay value does drop.Gameplay: 10--- This game is unique in this day and time and is truley something that should not be missed.  I can't remember how many times I laughed or got engrossed in the story that was unfolding before me.  The writing for this game is really awe inspiring and done quite well.  You get a real feeling of accomplishment when you piece clues together to get to the next part of your case.Overall: 9--- The only thing that keeps this from being game nirvana is the 3D engine being a bit dated.  That being said, the 3D environments looked good enough to me and they did quite well for the budget that BFG had.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Long ago, back when multimedia was king and the future of video games was clearly going to be fueled by low budget actors performing in front of green screens so that viewers could watch cut scenes in tiny pixelated boxes, there was only one name in private investigation. That name was Tex Murphy. Over the course of the 1990s, Tex stumbled his way through five point and click adventures, most of which were highlighted by the same FMV goodness that made Mad Dog McCree a household name. Now, thanks to the magic of crowdfunding and nostalgia, Tex is back for a new adventure in 2014, ready to take advantage of both the lowered expectations of FMV games and the high quality cameras available in our own far flung future. Tesla Effect nails it when it comes to weird video insanity, but drops the ball when it comes to basic gameplay. This shouldn’t matter for FMV fans who’ve been waiting for a new fix since Lococycle, but fans of point and clicks may not be satisfied with what’s presented here.Read the rest of my review over at Geekenstein.com! http://www.geekenstein.com/tesla-effect-tex-murphy-adventure-review/

content:
Posted: February 11
												Simply fantastic!  Played the Tex Murphy series in the 90s and missed these types of games.  Only found out they made a new one just last month (Jan 2017).  I am so delighted they stayed true to the original winning formula.  It has the same flavor as the games of the 90s except with upgraded video and graphics.  The acting, makeup, story, old detective noir vibe gives the game a ton of character.  It is just a satisfying adventure game that is fun to play.Liked: - 2K high resolution video - Smooth controls when moving through the world - Great storyline - Great characters - Built in many nostalgic throwbacks to the 90s games - Fun puzzles that give a sense of accomplishment - Sufficiently long gameplayCould Improve: - Although the puzzles were fun, some of them could be a bit more challenging - SFX volume seemed a bit inconsistent (too loud in some areas while reasonable in others) even though you can adjust it in the menu - the point system could have been explained a bit better (although it isn't very important, I found)If you like adventure games, play this one.  Here's to hoping they continue making these fantastic games!

Posted: March 9, 2016
												I've never played the old Tex Murphy games, but I thought this game was ok. I got it on sale for $4, and it was certainly worth it for that price. However, I wouldn't buy it for $20 unless you are a Tex Murphy fan.The good:The live action videos were actually pretty well done, and the story was better than I expected. The environment looks pretty good, and Tex makes subtle jokes all time when you click on various things. There are also random puzzles scattered around that must be completed to unlock containers or doors. These puzzles don't really fit the story, but I enjoyed them nonetheless.The bad:The gameplay eventually becomes burdensome, and I just wanted to get to the next part of the story. For a while wandering around and looking for clues was interesting, but eventually it becomes so annoying walking back and forth to pick up this, activate that, pickup this, bring it over there, etc. I guess that sort of thing can be considered a puzzle, but it is like a puzzle where upon figuring out what to try next, you have to walk for 2 minutes to the proper location to try it (and sometimes avoid obstacles like landmines). Basically too much of the game is spent walking around, wasting the player's time. I would like to see the other endings, but I am afraid it will take too much time to see them. I also don't know which decisions caused the ending I got or how to get the other endings.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Ahh, Tesla Effect. How hard it is to review it. One one hand, this is AMAZING reboot of a FMV adventure series. On the other hand... its a FMV adventure, packed with some of the same issues it used to have back then, and a few new ones packed in. Yes, we still have some amateurish acting in here. Yes, we still have bad looking rendered backgrounds that don't mesh too well with the characters. And we also have another issue here: after 16 years, the actors aren't exactly at their prome. Hell, one of the main characters looks so old (and fatter) compared to his/her last game that it kinda ruined some scenes in the game. And that's one of the main issues with the FMV genre...As an adventure game, Its a great entry. It does have a few casual puzzles (you know, the ones you usually find in hidden object games - sliding, jigsaw, etc), but there are also some amazingly designed ones, and the detective stuf is till top notch. You can open every drawer, you can look at every corner of the maps, you can still click in everything just to hear Tex cracking some jokes... Fact is: even if the game is indeed flawed, its easy to forget about the issues when you have a game that delivers EXACTLY what the fans where looking for: an answer to the question that has been living on our brains ever since we saw the end of Overseer. And unlike most recent adventure games, you DO have a nice inventory management, including the ability to combine items. Yeah, like the classics. ^^Much like Pandora Directive, Tesla Effect features two things that are usually NOT found in FMV games: branching dialogue trees and multiple endings. This is nice, because it gives you a reason to replay the game. The story will be the same, but you'll be able to see different dialogues, different scenes and different endings (there are 5 of them, BTW). The story, BTW, is, in my opinion, amazing. Very complex, very detailed and very creative. It VERY fictional, but not absurd. While it continues from the cliffhanger ending presented in Overseer, it also features a new plot, involving Nikola Tesla's inventions and some urban legends around it. In fact, the connections between all the older games and this new plot are so natural that you REALLY have to congratulate Chris Jones for its amazing writing.The gameplay is actually quite good. You still are able to navigate full 3D backgrounds in first person view, but all dialogues and most actions are presented in FMV scenes with branching  dialogues. You don't really choose WHAT Tex is gonna say, but HOW he will deliver his next line (sarcastic retort, weird PI humor, change subject, etc). This is nice, since you never know what he is gonna say until he does. This game has two difficulty settings, but unlike the older games, you have can select between casual, which is VERY easy, and gamer, which is just "normal". Yeah, this game doesn't present too much challenge for classic adventure players. But it's still harder than most adventure games coming out nowdays, and still feels like a real game, not an interactive movie, which is nice.The graphics are ok. For some lame reason, they decided to use Unity (YUCK!), so expect unstable framerates, VERY low res textures and weird 3D models. But the game doesn't really look BAD. Hell, for a budget game, some places are actually quite pleasing to the eyes. The FMV scenes are fantastic though. Not only they are in a very high resolution (blu-ray quality!), but most of them are quite well produced (the ending scenes specially have amazing special effects!). The sound department is perfect. The sound effects are realistic and VERY atmospheric and the musics are great and always set the right mood to most scenes. I have nothing to complain about the soundtrack. Heck, they even put the UAKM day transition song in here!! :pAnyway... Tesla Effect isn't perfect. It doesn't poop on Tex Murphy's name, and actually make it even stronger. In fact, its a better game that most people expected, and considering how dead the FMV genre is, its amazing that we got a new game that feels so similar to the older ones. It's a game that REALLY delivers to fans of the series. If you are not a fan though... well, I recommend that you try the demo first, because this game is aimed at the fans. I give this game an 9/10. And I REALLY hope they do a new one in the near future. At least before the actors get even older. :p

												This is hands down the best drawer simulator I have ever played. Do you like opening drawers and also closing them?  This is the simulator for you.  The drawers available run the gamut: from desk drawers to kitchen drawers to bedside table drawers - this game has them all.  Even better there is a narative that gives a back story as to why you are opening and closing the drawers, unlike those other lame drawer simulators.  Many drawers are not accessible until you have opened and closed other drawers that contain items of great importance such as glue and baseball cards!  As you gradually open a close various drawers, others will become available for you to access.In addition to the drawers there are also  cabinets that need to be opened or closed  !You can forget all the other drawer simulator games you've played. content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Easily the best adventure of the last 10 years. Tesla Effect will not disapoint, I highly recommend you buy this game. Unlike other adventure game titles such as Gone Home, which takes place in one location, has only one very anticlimatic ending and is devoid of multipathing, Tesla Effect is a big game with many vast locations, 5 unique endings, 3 narrative paths and a truly immersive story. The game engine is intuitive and fun to use, the graphics are very servicable considering the budget of just $1 million dollars and the 2K video footage is truly sublime. It's a game with enormous replay value and more than 30 hours of gameplay. For just $20, you should buy this instead of Gone Home, which is the same price BTW and can be finished in 45 seconds if you unlock all areas. Big Finish Games should be most proud of this magnifcant installment in the Tex Murphy game franchise.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Tesla Effect is a love letter to the old FMV genre that stands on its own merits as a modern title. You play as a bumbling cybernoir detective named Tex Murphy in this reboot of a series that had its last installment in 1998. This game was crowdfunded by fans so newcomers (like myself) can feel a little lost but the story opens with Tex losing his memory of the last seven years which can help ease you in to the universe.The gameplay is fairly simple. Full motion video cutscenes are separated by 3D envrionments that you must explore to find clues and solve puzzles in order to progress. The puzzles are not very difficult and you'll find most of the challenge comes from finding small items hidden in obscure locations. These scenes are made more lively with Tex's commentary as you observe different items in the games world. Depending on how observant and you are and your profficency for puzzle-sloving this game will vary from around 8 to 16 hours. I took just shy of 14 hours to complete my first playthrough and the only other FMV title I have played is the old X-Files game.The real charm from this game comes from its characters and acting. It feels like watching a cheesy B-Movie in the best way possible. There are some real gems of good delivery to be found complemented by awkward lines that will make you grin. Tex himself is absolutely lovable and you will meet several genuinely interesting people along the way. The game doesn't take itself too seriously and focuses on being as enjoyable as possible.Overall it's a well-executed modern interpretation of the old FMV adventure games and I am so glad I picked it up. If you are on the fence watch the "OMG FMV GOTY" trailer (it should be the first video on the store page). It sold me on buying this in under four minutes and I haven't looked back since.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Good Ol' Tex Is Back:If you're a fan of old school point & click adventure games, you probably know who Tex Murphy is.  For those that don't, Tex Murphy is a perpetually down on his luck, old school, wisecracking private eye, in the vein of Sam Spade.  The games take place in the near future, but with a distinctly Film Noir vibe to them.  They are a series of FMV-heavy point & click adventure games where Tex generally starts out with what seems like a simple case that leads him into conspiracies and wacky cults seemingly over his head.  Through a combination of investigative skills, wit, charm, and dumb luck, you, as Tex, must solve the case and save the world.This game, 16 years after the release of the previous Tex game, Overseer, is a Tex game through and through.  It plays just like the old games, albeit better looking and with a more modern interface.  The gist is still the same and the game has the same self-depreciating humor of the old Tex games.  It also packs a ton of fan service.  If you're new to the series you will miss a lot of references, but they're not critical to the enjoyment of the game.Like any point & click the game is filled with puzzles.  Most of them aren't too difficult, but there's at least some challenge to some of them.  Best of all, none of them are completely nonsensical, they at least make some sense, even if it is in a cartoonish way.  Like previous Tex games, the game is very heavy on dialogue, even more so than most point & clicks, and you have options to how you want to talk to people, generally giving you options to try to be charming, be a smartass, play it straight, and so on.  You also get to make some choices during the game and there are multiple endings.  I've only gotten one so far, but I intend to play the game again in the future to get the rest.The game took me a little over 14 hours to complete, which is pretty meaty for a point & click.  In my experience, most point & clicks last 8-12 hours.Visually, the game is a mixed bag.  The FMV video is super high resolution and quite nice, while many of the textures are kinda low res and sometimes clash with the FMV.  It;s not exactly a big budget game so I'm more surprised by how great the FMV looks rather than how low res the textures are.On the audio front, as in previous Tex games, the voice acting is all over the place, from amateurish and cheesy to professional and high quality.  This strange mix has always worked before in Tex games, and it works well here as well.  I think because the game doesn't take itself too seriously the cheesy acting winds up being a plus rather than a negative.Overall, it's a very enjoyable game.  If you're a fan of Tex then it's a no-brainer.  In fact, whay are you still reading this?  You should be playing the game right now.  If you're a fan of point & click adventures you will most likely like this game.  If you don't like point & click adventures, this game won't change your mind.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Having played the game from start to finish with just work and sleep in the way, it's safe to say I really enjoyed it.  Is it for everyone?  Absolutely not.  Is there things I did not like - absolutely.  The game is very archaic in everything outside of its cutscenes and dialogue.  The game relies on almost 3D-like pixel hunting to find items in the inventory.  I cannot tell you how many times I was stuck because I couldnt find an item that was hidden or under a table or in a dark corner.  The puzzles rage from borderline  easy to incredibly obtuse/time consuming.  Most of it results in trial and error.  Some puzzles dont have solutions when you think there would be.  When you get stuck, especially on Gamer mode when there is no hint, expect to take a few dozen minutes to hours to find that random item you need to complete a puzzle.The game also includes something which I found very distracting/annoying - a computer companion named (Smart) Alex.  I understand why he's in the game as hes pretty much the only one you have with you at all times and gives the game needed exposition from time to time.  However for the most part I found his prescense annoying, he detracted from the immersion.  This is however a minor detail, or nitpick.The gameworld is pretty hollow, or empty.  Mean Streets is the same you remember, almost too similar.  You cant explore stores anymore and the characters you talk to from previous games seem to be just there to forward the plot.  Its pretty remarkable to get most if not all of the original cast back but none of them actually do anything for the plot other than forward it to the next scene.  Probably a smaller game world next time will make the game feel less barren.  Currently you're feel like you're on rails - going from one plot point to another until you're in a completely different location and doing the same thing but this time trying to find items to complete puzzles.I have played all the 3D Tex Murphy games, although this game is excellent I personally feel Pandora Directive is better but only because of the game world.  As previously mentioned, where this game excells is the video quality and quantity.  There is a staggering amount of detail in the game world.  It is unfortunetely however how convuleted the plot is at times - how the characters will reference or drop information as it was already common knowledge.  There are several times when they will say something critical or profound and just say, "Oh I'm sure you know this already Tex."  I dont know if this is intentional as the basic plot deals with Tex losing his memory, or because the plot branches so much but its very jarring.  It creates a disconnect with the plot and in the end I had no idea what was going on, or probably as much as Tex did.  Maybe it would be different on a different path?I would recommend this game first to previous players of Tex Murphy games - it will be interesting to see if multiple playthroughs make the plot more coherent.  Also due to the branching paths it will be interesting if theres different areas or puzzles that open up with it as well.  If you're new to Tex Murphy or even old school pixel hunt adventure games I'd try the demo first.  If I could give this game a score, it would be a 7 out of 10.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												I've played a lot of computer games over the years but the Tex Murphy games were, without a doubt, the ones I loved the most "back in the day." We had to wait 16 years for a conclusion to Overseer and I have to say, it was worth the wait. Is it perfect, of course not. No game is. However, it ran perfectly on my machine and the video looked fantastic! The gameplay was fun and the puzzles, at least on the casual setting, were challenging without being frustrating. If you were a fan of Tex, you'll most likely enjoy this game. If you weren't, give it a try. While there are a lot of dialogue references (and objects that trigger flashbacks) to the earlier games, it is a complete story by itself. If you like adventure games, I'm betting you'll enjoy Tesla Effect.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												Tex Murphy was a staple of my growth into manhood and I have an incredible amount of nostalgia for the old series. When Tesla Effect hit Steam, I purchased immediately, because I had a feeling they were going to deliver and make a decent adventure game.Man, was I way off-mark.They made an INCREDIBLE adventure game. Like, really friggin' nailed it. Most adventure games nowadays suffer from uninventive puzzles (use a broom to sweep, use gun to shoot), but Tex Murphy is the first game in the last decade that has made me feel like I was enjoying the adventure games of my youth, exploring and inspecting everything, fitting together random, disparate items in hopes of gaining some positive outcome. And, more often than not, the game can be brain-bendingly difficult, which means that finally discovering the answer is so incredibly satisfying.Big Finish Games really struck the anvil while the fire was hot with this game. The music is amazing. The cutscenes and atmosphere are dead-on some of the best cyberpunk/noirpunk I've seen, and the FMV in this game is far and above the best I've seen across any medium. Even the actors are quite good at keeping you immersed in the game.There are only a few problems. The textures are fairly low-resolution in the game, but considering the amount of FMV and the fact that the game is a love-letter to late 80s-early 90s adventure games and isn't over 30gigs, I'm completely okay with it. The game is of a really decent length, but a lot of that may have been because I spent so much time exploring every possible nook and cranny, so you could feasibly finish this game in a few short hours by powering through. Additionally, there were some areas where I found a few holes in the world that I couldn't get through, but could still see through the map, which is a bit of a problem.Otherwise, though, this game is a solid 9 out of 10 for me. If you aren't a fan of the originals, this might be a pass for you, but I highly recommend at least giving the demo a shot and deciding for yourself if you want to purchase it, because I guarantee it is at least worth some of your time. This is the first time I have ever seen a franchise resurrect itself in another era of electronic media and not only pay PERFECT homage to it's predecessors, but grown and delivered a compelling experience of it's own. It's also the only adventure game I've played that understands it's audience's sense of humor and level of maturity.Please please please give this game a chance, for your own sake, and support a great developer, so they continue delivering amazing gaming experiences.-Palin"Danger is like Jello. There's always room for more." - Tex Murphy

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Tex Murphy: Tesla Effect is a very good adventure game with a plot worthy of the series. Being an FMV game might turn some people off, but it’s worth checking out if you’re a fan of noir or apocalyptic stories. More casual players might shy away from it, particularly those who aren’t big fans of tough puzzles, but over 7,000 people had faith in the concept to make the game a reality. It’s not without its flaws, but thanks to two different difficulty settings most of these can be overlooked or worked around. While it’s not classic point-and-click, the first person exploration might bring over shooter fans who want a more relaxed exploration-based title that uses controls very similar to today’s FPS games.http://www.kickstartadventure.com/home/tex-murphy-tesla-effect-review/

content:
Posted: February 7
												I really liked this game.  One of the best point and click adventures I have ever played.  The 3D rendered environments are nothing special by today's standards.  The puzzles are challenging but not impossible.  The charm is a great story - well written, well executed with very clever dialog.  The video cut scenes are terrific. I give this game 8.5 out of 10.  I played it for about 15 hours and enjoyed it immensely.  Definitely worth picking up in one of the seasonal sales.This was my first Tex Murphy game and I did not know what to expect.  I was a bit disappointed initially - you have to play the game for a bit before it shows its magic. Be sure to watch the credits right to the end as there is a funny news report after the names of the Kickstarter Supporters roll past. I bought this on sale but I would have been happy if I had paid full price.  I hope that Big Finish Games makes a sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I'm on Day 3 and it's been great fun so far. I'm playing it with the girlfriend and its a perfect little game to sit down to together and play on the steam controller.I've never played the originals, so I'm new to the series, but from what I can see they stick very true to the original series.Pros:- Funny Dialogue- Mostly good acting- Runs very smoothly- Handles good, particularly first person sections.- Difficulty isn't too obscurely difficult, nor too easy. I'd compare it to the level of difficulty of Toonstruck.- The quality of the game is seriously impressive considering their $700,000 budget.- Music is great.Cons:- The interface can be a little fiddly, especially with steam controller.- The FMV quality often has the greenscreen cast a shade of greeen on the characters, this breaks the immersion a bit.- The absence of a "journal" worries me that I might forget what i'm supposed to be doing if I take a long break from the game.- Some of the 3D textures are pretty terrible.All in all, a refreshing FMV experience. They have successfully put down a modern twist on a classic genre, without butchering the things that made the originals so good.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												A quirky point and click adventure that pokes fun at itself but isn't over the top aside from the story which can be tough to follow at times.The game is fairly linear, without there being too much to explore in terms of side stories but the decisisons you make will affect the end of the game. I've played Quest for Glory, Kings Quest, Sam and Max; if you enjoy point and click adventure games this is a solid pickup. You'll spend more time solving the slide puzzle than you will on the rest of those games.And there's a casual mode that lets you skip puzzles in case you don't want to play the game that you just purchased.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1
												If you are a fan of the series, you have to get this game. It improves on nearly every aspect of the previous games and looks so much better.Pros Greatly improved interface, much easier to navigate and collect items.Interesting story.All the original main cast are back (with the exception of Mac Malden who passed away).Great soundtrack.FMV quality is excellent.Return of the "Day" system, breaking the game into easily digestible chunks.Lots of fun.Cons.The graphics, while a massive improvement on the previous games, are a little dated.The last act is a little weak.Not necessarily a con, but the first person collection is a lot simpler, only a few items are in each room.If you aren't a fan of the original, I'd recommend The Poisoned Pawn, a prequel that is under development, to get caught up, then this game.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Tesla Effect is overall a fun adventure and a great tribute to the original series of games.Moving around is now done in a nice FPS-style which definitely makes it easier.The puzzles can be quite difficult, also in a large part due to the fact that they're part of the game world instead of on an overlay or a new screen. Unfortunately this means sometimes the puzzles become a bit too zoomed out to easily read, at least on a television screen.There are a lot of references to the old games, but I think that if you love cheesy FMV games you'll still get a kick out of this one even if you haven't played any of the previous ones.As a fan, I could buy and play one of these every year or so.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												If you were both a mystery lover and a PC Gamer in the early 90s, the name Tex Murphy must certainly make you smile. His games felt real, the stories were fantastically well-crafted and mysterious, the characters were all engaging, sometimes funny and other times intimidating, and the puzzles made your head spin. Sadly, these games were casted into oblivion by modern pop-style blockbuster video games, were the "X" that marked the spot was as big as a planet. When I heard that the team that made the Tex Murphy adventures was back, I gave them my support, and thank god I did! Tesla Effect is certainly not a game for everyone, it has its flaws and its virtues, and that's quite alright. Do yourself a favor and play this game for all those times you wished you could live inside a futuristic dystopian movie. Put on your fedora hat and live a Tex Murphy adventure!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Brings me back to the glory days of the "Future of Video Games" when Sega Saturn launched FMV games. However, this is the only game that has successfully melded the game and full motion video. All other previous hybrids I have played before have been misreable failures.And even though I hadnt heard of Tex Murphy before this game its very easy to jump right into the story, identify with Tex, and realize that the pulp and noire feel just works seamlessly. Tex really needs no intro. Prior to starting the game I feared there was going to be too many references that were inside jokes from previous chapters of the Tex Murphy saga. Im glad to say that this stands alone well and everyone can get the same level of enjoyment whether they were very involved with previous storylines or are a total newcomer like myself.Easily a 4.5 out 5 stars. The half star deduction will be explained later. But its nothing that should stop you from getting the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												This is the first time I ever played a Tex Murphy game and I must say, it was better than I expected.  It isn't a great game, but it is very good.  It was nice to see that the developers brought back the FMV format, I haven't seen that since Myst IV, Revelation.Pros:Good story-lineThe puzzles are well balancedDecent graphicsRespectable actingFor the most part, the humor was well doneFive different endings, each with it's own set of consequencesFull Motion Video (depending on your preference, this could be a con)Cons:No real detective work, just follow the clues until you finish the gameSome of the jokes fall flat (can't hit a home run every time)There are two things that I really, REALLY hate in gaming and I mean HATE with a capital H.  One is mazes.  The maze in The Tesla Effect isn't that hard but the developers had the audacity to combine it with the other thing I hate... spiders.  I despise those eight legged freaks of nature.  As I already stated, the maze isn't that hard, even with those disgusting arachnids, but still.  I had to shower after I navigated through that hideous maze.Other than that, I'll have to give this game a thumbs up and I look forward to playing it again and trying out the other endings, the only thing is... that damn maze and those things.At the time of this review, The Tesla Effect was selling for $19.99, is it worth that?  I think so... but barely.  I got it on sale so I was very pleased.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Sweet live action sequences! Awesome flying cars! Well-designed post-apocalyptic world! Interesting and engrossing puzzles. Great FPS point-and-click adventure with multiple endings!Only things that were an issue for me were sometimes, you think you're standing in a safe place (behind a forcefield, for instance), but you still get hit. And sometimes the clues aren't obvious as to where you need to go to get what you need to acquire, but not often: Explore thoroughly and always check for table drawers! The last puzzle requires a bit of rote memorization, or possibly a notepad. But all in all, it's a great game! Recommended to anyone who's enjoyed any of the old games!

												As someone who backed this game on Kickstarter I may be a bit biased, but basically if you enjoyed the previous adventures of Tex or like adventure games in general then it's well worth the low price of $20, else if it ever goes on sale then definitely pick it up.The graphics may not be the greatest and the storyline gets a little distorted under it's own weight and hard to follow about half way through, but it's still a very enjoyable few hours with some good laughs and some solid performances throughout the FMV sequences.If nothing else, it's proof that Kickstarter can result in a successful game launch.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Often when old series are revived in modern installments, the gameplay is changed or dumbed down to appeal to modern audiences, leaving fans alienated.  Not so with Tesla Effect. The gameplay is more or less identical to the last few efforts,  for good or ill. While not as fiendishly difficult as Under a Killing Moon or TPD, there are still puzzles to be found sprinkled throughout the game. There are many surprisingly well-acted and high budget, high-resolution FMVs, some great humour and alternate endings depending on some decisions taken. Weaknesses are the length and the way the story seems to fizzle out half way through (many major plot events are simply left hanging).

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												This is your 2014 Game Of The Year.Yes, its old school. Yes some of the graphic can be a little dated and the "NPC's" are not of the state of the art.Big deal.This game trumps all recent adventure titles in the past 10 years and makes the much ballyhooed The Walking Dead look like a indie turd by comparison. For 20 bucks, you will get 15 hours of pure-gaming-bliss.I was a backer, and I was a fan of the original Tex titles, but this is the best Tex EVER, beating out the legendary Pandora Directive. You owe it to yourself to buy this game, grab a nice drink, a bag a chips, a pair of headphones and some quality alone time with your PC.Out of all the games being made today, with the huge budgets, advanced graphic technology and women used as sex objects, its refreshing to see this game, with an amazing yet mature storyline comne out that puts the rest of the industy to shame.Bravo Chis Jones and Big Finish, this game rocks, now don't wait almost 20 years for the next one, we backers will back you as long as you need us and as long as you keep making games THIS GOOD!

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I loved this game. So much so that I am actually bothering to write a review for it. Which I don't often do.Everything in this game captures what a Tex Murphay game is and what a Tex Murphy game should be. Humor, intelligent puzzles that aren't obtuse, mystery, and a brancing story line. I thoroughly enjoyed every second of my first playthrough so much that as soon as the credits were done rolling I started a second playthrough right away.While the 3D enviornments you explore in game are average at best the game lives and dies by it's astonishingly beautiful FMV. I played a lot of FMV games back when they were popular and even as a fan I understood why the meduim fell out of favor. They were expensive to produce and video quality was low. There is no evidence of that here. The video is beautiful, every scene helps to draw you in and increase your immersion.If you have any appreciation at all for adventure games you should play this. Even if you've never played another Tex Murphy game you should play this because it's a great example of the form.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Tesla Effect is a MIRACLE.See, I was hoping for this game long for its Kickstarter, long before these was ever a glimmer of hope that there could be a new Tex Murphy game. Now, here it is. It's a dream come true! T.E. is everyhing I'd hoped it would be, and more.The cutscens are where the $$$ went in this game, and it shows. The acting is pretty good, with only 1 or 2 exceptions. Chris Jones is back again as Tex Murphy and it's wonderful to see him on screen again. He's not really an actor, but his talent and charm is what makes all the Tex games so special.Chris also designed the puzzles, as before. They are hard, but not too hard, and you'll be hunting for objects too, like any Adventure game. There are 2 modes: causal and gamer.I'm really happy with the way the game looks and feels. But Is the game kinda ugly? Well... yes, sometimes. The textures are not that complex, and neither are the 3D models. It has the looks of a game from about 2005. But please remember, this is not a AAA title. It's a small company indie game, and there were only about 3 dudes working on the levels. But I never really noticed any of that. For $20, you can't go wrong! There are different story paths to follow, and multiple endings, so it's always worth playing again.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												First and foremost, this game is for Tex Murphy fans. If you haven't played any of the old games, you probably won't like this one, unless you are a fan of the puzzle adventure genre. If you have played the old games you will not be disappointed. This is a classic Tex Murphy adventure with all the old humor and even the odd flash back to moments from the old games. The acting is pretty average and yes you can see actors occassionally reading from the cue cards, but that's just how all Tex games are and I wouldn't have it any other way! The use of the Unity engine breathes new life into the world although some areas appear to have been rushed and a lot of textures are below par for what I would expect from todays games. On the other hand the full motion HD video is top-notch, a massive leap forward over the older games. It could have been easy for these guys to change the formula and go down a more open-world route with this game but they've stuck to the old formula well and it's a credit to them, it works and provides a nice bit of nastalgia. I got about 11 hours of play out of it, and thats just the first path I haven't replayed the different paths yet. So for $20 it's great value classic puzzle advernturing.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Tesla Effect is one massive love letter to 90s FMV adventure gaming, and a *very* faithful follow-up to a long-gone series (for better and for worse).Working with their lite Kickstarter budget, Big Finish Games delivered a full-length adventure game loaded with (generally) well-acted cutscenes, great music, devious puzzles and alternate endings. They had a lot of ambition going into this project, and they somehow managed to pull it together into a solidly engaging 10+ hours of detective-ing. Sure, the game's central plot - in which our hapless hero attempts to piece together the last seven years of his life, whilst on the trail of Tesla's lost inventions - is convoluted and sometimes poorly explained...and the humour frequently dives into dated dad joke territory...but if you're at all interested in this series or 90s adventure gaming in general, this is a solid addition to your library.Be warned though: the game also revives some of the major faults of 90s adventure gaming. Several sections of this game suffer from severe pixel-hunting-itis (less of a problem in Casual Mode, but potentially rage-inducing on the standard difficulty setting), there are some minor awful stealth segments, there's an extremely lazy bit where you have to solve a "the chicken and the fox can't be on the same boat" puzzle...and yes, there's even a maze full of spiders. Still, it's nothing worse than what the 90s threw at us. It's worth bearing through it for the overwhelmingly fun, nostalgic, and authentic Tex Murphy experience that this game has on offer. Thumbs up from me!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The reviews for this game were pretty mixed, but I decided to pick it up anyway. I'm completely new to the Tex Murphy games and FMV games a whole. The only others I'd really seen were the phantasmagoria games and the handful of Wing-commander games in the same format, which were kinda like interactive movies. This game is no different, but it was cool to see a dead genre reborn. The game was definately one for the fans, and you can tell a lot more work went into the FMV sequences rather than the game-play itself. The acting is very cheesy a lot of the time, just like most FMV games. For example, in at least two scenes, actors were supposed to be dead, but you could see them still breathing. The puzzles in the game were pretty basic and the puzzle difficulty ranged tremendously throughout the game. Sometimes I had to use brute force to pass a puzzle, other times I managed to solve them very quickly. With all this said, I still really liked the game and would happily buy and play a sequel. Hopefully we may also see other FMV games return in the future.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Just finished TE and found it to be one of the most enjoyable games I have played. Now, fair warning, this is a point-and-click adventure game, so if you do not like that type of game, then you probably won't love it the way I do. However, if you do like that genre, this is a wonderful game for you. If you played any or all of the Tex Murphy games from about ten years ago--Under a Killing Moon, The Pandora Directive--then you are in for a double treat. Many of your favorite characters are back, and Tex is played by the same actor with all the wisecracking and corny P.I. jokes (of course). One of the things I got the biggest kick from is the flashback sequences drawn from the old games triggered by objects in the environment (remembering how Tex got a hole in the brim of one of his fedoras was one of my favorites). The flashbacks appear to be the FMV from the old games displayed in a little letterbox in the center of the screen. The new FMV shot for this game is high-def and full screen and looks and plays beautifully. There is a casual mode for beginners with hints as to what to do next and objects that are needed for the story highlighted by Tex's trusty flashlight. More experienced adventure gamers are going to want to play without the hints or the object-highlighting, but either way this is a great ride--especially if you played any of the earlier games. I played without the help, and while there are a few items that took a bit of work to find and a challenging timed puzzle at the end of the game, I only had to rely on the Universal Hint System two or three times. So a great point-and-click adventure for anyone, and a special treat for Tex Murphy fans from earlier games, Tesla Effect is not to be missed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Tesla Effect is the latest game in the Tex Murphy series, a first person point and click adventure game with a heavy emphasis on FMVs (full motion video). FMVs were quite popular in the early nineties because computer graphics still weren't able to provide a good character representation. However they fell out of favour because most of them had bad gameplay and even worse acting. The only games I played which really used FMV effectively were the Command & Conquer games. The FMVs there felt like a reward for progressing through the story.In Tesla Effect I get a similar feeling, I enjoyed most of the FMV sections. Mostly because of the protagonist Tex Murphy, who is played in a very self aware manner, the game knows it's cheesy and doesn't take itself too seriously. And if you strip away all the videos there's still a pretty good game underneath it all. While the 3D graphics certainly aren't anything to special (they look like something out of a decade old game) they were actually better than I expected, especially since the levels themselves are reasonably large. I am pleased with the size of the world they constructed, there isn't that much of revisiting the same locations and they are quite varied as well. However pretty much the whole 3D world is dead, there are very few encounters with living beings outside of the FMVs.The story itself is cheesy and by the end of the game I felt it became pretty much ridiculous. The game played much better when it wasn't focusing on the main premise of the game. It would have been nice to have some side quests, but in true adventure game fashion every single thing is connected and you can not progress without doing everything. I wouldn't fault most other adventure games with this, however as I mentioned I felt the game was best when it wasn't focusing on the main story.The videos themselves are quite well made, the acting is cheesy but not bad. There are barely any real world objects, almost everything besides the characters themselves is CGI, which is on par with the rest of the game. So, not great, but considering the budget they had to work with I think it's good enough.As an adventure game there are quite a lot of puzzles, I was OK with most of them, however I certainly needed help sometimes. Thankfully there's an optional help system included in the game and an option to skip the puzzle mini game sections, which I used once because the puzzle itself made absolutely no sense to me.Tesla Effect is not an easy game to recommend, it's a throwback to a type of game which existed for a very short amount of time, due to limited technical capabilities of the time. And the series from which it comes is probably one of the best of its type. When I played the game I took it as such and mostly enjoyed what I got, so if you do the same you can go ahead and try this out. I hope the series continues, as I think a really good game can be made from this, with the right story.6 / 10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I'll preface this by saying that I've never played a Tex Murphy Adventure before Tesla Effect.  They were very much on my radar and I remember quite well wanting to play Under a Kiling Moon when I was young.  FMV games for the most part were a flash in the pan fad that really overstayed their welcome in the early/mid 90's.  Some did it very well and are among my favorite adventures (Gabriel Knight 2: The Beast Within,) some were flawed but still highly enjoyable (Phantasmagoria) and some were pretty abysmal (anything released on Sega CD.)  Tesla Effect falls promptly into the middle catagory. The story, characters, presentation and FMV are pretty fantastic.  The acting is terrible but in the best possible way.  Any positive things I have to say about this game all center around those aspects.  The game environment and gameplay on the other hand did leave quite a bit to be desired.  The world itself is pretty ugly by todays standards.  It was like navigating a 1999 poly environment.  I guess you could argue that works for the game since it's a return to a medium long dead since the 90's. The gameplay relies HEAVILY on finding items as every adventure games should.  The real trouble here is that the items and world are so murky and blocky that they blend together.  I highly recommend playing on "casual" settting because your flashlight will call sparkly attention to these things.  Even then it was still difficult finding them.  I feel bad for complaining about this game because it has so much character.  I just wish more time and effort were put into the gameplay.   Also I hugely enjoyed the easter eggs that pulled video from the original Tex adventures.  They really made me want to go back and see what I was missing.  Sadly they were missing from the final half of the game or I was just missing them.  Still a recommended play for anyone looking for a nostalgic trip back to 90's FMV

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I wasted many hours of my youth in the 90's playing the Tex Murphy Adventures and it's great to see it back without being changed, updated, adjusted or mutilated for todays modern audience. It doesn't need it! It’s great to see a classic style game brought to life with the same love, care and attention that was given to the originals. From the funny, over the top but brilliant acting in the FMV scenes, to the vivid albeit dated graphics and interesting story, the game is a work of art. The story, while perhaps not quite upto the standards of previous adventures, is fun and keeps you interested throughout. Fantastic game. Other developers should take note and could learn a lot from this! Buy it now!Pros+Tex is back!!!+Great to see an old series brought back to life in the same spirit as previously without ruining it+Brilliant acting+HD FMV+In places it’s hilarious +Interesting and challenging puzzles+Decent story+Good sound and music+Runs great with few bugs - uses the Unity EngineCons-Interface is not the greatest-Graphics are dated (though this is not really a down side and has no negative impact in the game, they just could have been a bit better)

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												A great pulpy detective story, marred by plodding hidden object searches, and generic adventure game puzzles. The characters and cutscenes are superbly written and a joy to behold, and the game really hits its peak when it gives you a mystery to unravel and an open space for you to find clues within.However, half the game's puzzles seem to exist just to exist. Too often I was left in an interesting location, with uninteresting objectives. At one point, I found a sliding block puzzle in an old woman's mansion and simply quit because it completely broke immersion for me.Still, an enjoyable experience, and a tentative recommendation. However, if you're looking for gameplay that actually makes you feel like a detective, I'd recommend the Sherlock Holmes' or Blackwell series' instead.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												"Save me Tex Murphy! You're my only hope!" 7/10I should mention that I had never heard of ‘Tex Murphy’ growing up in the 90’s. I guess the series was pretty popular though if they were able to get a Kickstarter to bring it back. Remember games that had cut scenes with actual people in them, almost like movies? Yeah, I had forgotten about them too. Having said all of that however, I still thoroughly enjoyed this game and would definitely recommend it to anyone who grew up in the 90’s playing FMV games. If you can get it for a low, low, oh-so-low price that is; I really can’t justify paying $20 for this game. Having said that, I really have no idea why I enjoyed this game. As I have already stated I had never heard of these games before a few weeks ago, so there really isn't any nostalgia there. The graphics are dated, the puzzles are tired and old, the atmosphere is dull and extremely basic, the story isn’t anything special, and the controls could be better. I mean sure, it's supposed to feel like those early 90’s PC games with live action, but this game is really pushing it with these graphics that look like they came straight out of 2006. But whatever, story and graphics aren’t everything that makes a game great. I mean who plays games for their stories?  This game is also pretty damn hard, even on the ‘casual’ mode. So be prepared to ask for some guidance along the way by seeking the in-game itinerary for where to go and what to do. I mean, unless you don’t mind wandering around for hours, aimlessly looking for objects that are sometimes pretty hard to see. See? Even as I’m writing this I’m still questioning why the hell I loved this game so much. And I truly did love this game. The acting definitely helps with that too, as I found myself getting more and more engrossed in the cut-scenes, watching this story I started out not caring about, unfold before my very eyes. Todd Bridges, some guy from some show, even makes an appearance. So in closing…this game is extremely dated with graphics from a decade ago, needs some fiddling to work with a controller, has ridiculous HD cut-scenes with sometimes stupid characters, has some stupid puzzles, and is a blast from start to finish. Go get em’ Tex…that’s not a line from the game but I think it fits quite nicely.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												An enjoyable, crowd-funded detective game that's really half-game, half-movie (it's a 16GB download!).  Good acting and interesting storyline that can branch into 5 different endings.   Except for some annoying 'jumping-through-the-hoops' at times (some puzzles and items quests were a bit 'unintuitive'...), it was, overall, an entertaining ride. Good writing and appropriate music, too.  On the downside, there are some graphic scenes of violence (Tex getting beaten unconscious with an iron rod, which I did NOT find funny...), depictions of decapitation, and certain 'adult' themes, all of which make this game inappropriate for pre-17s. What I also liked about it was that it appears to be designed to help raise awareness about the life of Nikola Tesla and his work.  If you get a chance, read up on some of Tesla's monumental discoveries and their importance in not just our daily lives (e.g. AC power, brushless motors, etc.) but also in the implementation of certain advanced technologies (e.g. wireless transmission of power, resonant systems, scalar electromagnetics, etc).  Helps fill in the missing 'forbidden' knowledge purposely omitted from most college-level Physics courses these days...Check it out.(Note: Acquired via a bundle)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I've been on Steam for a long time but this game is the first one to motivate me to write a review - it was that good :) As a hardcore point-and-click games fan, I somehow missed the hype around Tex Murphy series when previous installments were released. This is the first FMV game I've ever played and this is what I liked about it:- Quality of graphics and FMV scenes exceeded my expectations. Transitions between cutscenes and in-game content is smooth and 3D environments in general are a real eye candy (for a game this type)- Story is interesting, full of some (sometimes) cheesy humour but overall very engaging - the cheesy parts are actually funny and enjoyable rather than annoying. Acting is great but then again, you won't see much of acting from the secondary characters in the game (mostly short dialogues)- Puzzles are logical for an adventure game and mostly enjoyable rather than frustrating. The game auto-saves a lot, so even if you happen to die (which in some parts of the game may happen a bit more often), you won't have to replay anything- There is a decent hint system (pretty much an in-game walkthrough), so if you get stuck, you can always review the solution of this particular puzzle/episode of the game. I used the hint system a few times in the beginning of the game until I got used to the mechanics of character control and interaction and almost haven't used it since- Hunting for items/interactable objects can sometimes be a pain in the butt, since it's much harder to do pixel hunting in 3D environments as opposed to 2D environments used by most point and clicks/adventure games. I am playing the easy mode which makes an item "sparkle" when you use the flashlight but I still had some difficulties noticing several items in the game (they were only noticeable when Tex approaches them closely). I think that this happened 2-3 times so far, so definitely not a frustrating experience (if you play it on the hard mode, some items may be very challenging to find :))Playing the game felt a bit like L.A. Noire (due to its unique Film Noir like setting), a bit like Fallout 3 (in terms of exploring relatively spacy areas and buildings) and a lot like a very good adventure/point and click game. I even went ahead and bought all other Tex Murphy adventures even though I probably won't be able to stand the old graphics for too long but as all point-and-click games fans know, these games are not about the graphics (e.g. Wadget eye games) :)I sincerely hope they will make another one or remake one of the older ones - I will buy it instantly.

												With Tesla Effect, Big Finish Games and Atlus managed to take my breath away, which is something I haven't experienced in a long time. I love the old Tex, the humor, the plot, the silly FMV, the graphic style, the open locations, the popcultural references, the participation of known faces... But more than anything, I am grateful for the amount of pure fun the developers were able to concentrate in a single twenty dollar game. I really hope they can make a sequel, this is a top notch product and an instant classic.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Tesla Effect is the kind of a game I though I wouldn't be seeing again. While the gameplay itself is 1st person 3D, the game narrative uses FMV. It's a real flashback from the 90's, when FMV was the latest craze, only to die because of overuse in less than stellar games. Tex Murphy series never was bad though.In its day Tex Murphy games were one of the few that got FMV right. The games weren't poorly acted choose your own adventure types, but real, honest adventure games with exploration and character interactions. They were, and still are, good games. And then FMV died and so did Tex, at least so it seemed.Previous Tex game, The Overseer, left things in a cliffhanger. A cliffhanger, that would take over decade to be resolved. Tesla Effect doesn't continue directly from the end of the Overseer, but the mystery it left is part of the mystery that needs to be resolved in Tesla Effect as well. At the same time Tesla Effect is its own story, so being familiar with previous games isn't mandatory.While Tesla Effect is a bit lacking in graphics, especially in comparison to modern AAA games, it is a great game none the less and especially the FMV sequences look pretty damn good. So if you are a fan of adventures, or pulp sci-fi, then Tesla Effect might just be a game for you. I know it was a game for me.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Conclusion: I liked the game when I wasn't tearing my hair out because of having not found an item, but that's about all the challenge there is to the game. Definitely not for everyone, but one of the more enjoyable/better ways to giving FMV adventure games a chance once it inevitably lands in a sale. I'd expect this to be the best-looking adventure game with such focus on full-motion (greenscreened) live action video for a good while, if only because there probably won't be any more of the kind in several years.Gameplay: The bulk of the adventure is viewed from the first-person perspective and the player can walk freely around like in FPS games, except there's no jumping or crouching. In this mode, the game looks really ugly. Low-detail models, low-resolution textures, very few no character models (and those that are shown are usually even worse). The stealth and action sections are... something that can be cleared, but no highlights of the game. There are no ridiculous item combination puzzles, which is a big plus.Dialogue: The dialogue in the game is played by greenscreened live actors. In these, there are usually several options to pick from - two to three - but I can't say if they branch the game plot outside one or two rather obvious points. Once this dialogue tree is handled, it's back to picking one from the list of topics. I'd call the acting mostly passable - at least better than what is shown in the clips from the old games.Puzzles: When it comes to puzzles, it's nothing overly difficult. I don't recall any "how was I supposed to know I had to combine these?!" problems, and the "in-situ" puzzles (a Simon Says -puzzle, solving a board game problem, ...) are relatively straightforward, if you listen to Tex telling what you're supposed to do in it. (The board game, I'm talking about you!)Issues: For me, the biggest problem was finding all items. I played the game without the flashlight aiding me and I had to check a walkthrough maybe three times. (Wheel, hook, glue). Some items are hidden so well and/or in unlikely places, making the game too much like a 3D hidden object game. On the other hand - this is the investigation part that some might find interesting.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Ah damn, this is a hard review to do...Well, I love the serie, you know? I was so pleased to see a new episode coming out. FMV is all my youth after all. I rushed on Harvester when it was re-released, own both the 7th Guest and the 11th Hour and enjoy them almost as much as first time.And if I must be honnest I would go down on my knees for some Phantasmagoria or Gabriel knight but this is a totally different story.Ok, so this new Tex.Those new gen FMV's are gorgeous, I connected my notebook to my 55" TV and were all "WOW" like when I saw Tex HD. The intro is great, sweating Blade runner from all its pixels. The first minutes were plain joy, a nicely done optional tutorial and then, here I went on my own ready to investigate this new open world. Then...Well, yeah, then...THEN, I realized that the game is just no more than FMV's and a nice scenario continuing the main serie story.Let me explain myself, the game got a single and only bad point: it's realisation is rubbish. It seems like the team spent all the budget on the movie part and the rest of the game, the interractive "real" playable part, was build using HL 1 engine. It's cheap, cubic, empty for the most part with plenty of 3D models repetitions trying to furnish the maps but failed.The level design, if I can call it that way, is madly wrong and screams: "So boring to do those additional buildings, anyway you would have no interraction on them except maybe an optional object to find so why try harder".No joke, I saw some better textures on Minecraft...Click on one of those "useless buildings" and enjoy Tex repeating again and again the same comment.Countless amounts of objects here and there triggering some "flashback" style videos getting the player back to the old episodes of the serie but with no links with the actual story would then finish the work and make you understand that the Dev's are just imploring you hands joined to buy the older episodes.Another epic fail was the translation. For those who master english, no problem at all. Characters are all on ol'time noir movies slang and they sounds great.Heh, me bad. english isn't my mother's tongue so I turned on the subtitles. I'm not stupid. I pretty well know that slang or expressions are sometimes really hard to translate as they sometimes got no compare on another language but dude!Who the hell did you guys picked to do the job? We have litteral translation here, word for word. Not any comprehension of the original meaning and worst, on some dialogues with multi answers choice it becomes plain luck to choose witch one you must or want choose from...So after all that was said, you would certainly ask yourself: "So, good or not?"For myself, as a real lover of Tex' debuts, it will definitly be a YES. I played some serious ♥♥♥♥♥ way more awfull than that and enjoyed them.For new incomers, those who never played Under a Killing Moon and even don't know what is it, don't loose your time here.If you're just curious about the franchise, get yourself one of the firsts.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												a blasT froM The futurEI’ve been waiting for quite some time for Tex Murphy Tesla Effect to arrive, long before the Kick Starter campaign and anxiously ever since.I have a lot of fond memory from my childhood playing Under a Killing Moon, Pandora Directive and Overseer, I also tried playing Mean Street and Martian Memorandum, but those gave an entirely different experience from the FMV games and it did not appeal to me as much....and so came the big day, the 8th of may 2014, Tesla Effect was finally released.I tried pacing myself while playing it, but I couldn’t resist the temptation and ended up finishing it in 3 sessions of about 6 hours each.Tesla Effect delivers the essential elements of a Tex Murphy game and more, that being said there were a few things that bugged me which i will expand on shortly, but all and all, after finishing the game i felt like i got the experience i was looking and remembered so fondly.What is a Tex Murphy Game?Tex Murphy, is a First Person, FMV, Adventure game, that is very story driven and filled with amusing dialogues and challenging puzzles.So lets break it down to section:-First Person-In Telsa Effect there was a big improvement in the controls and navigation through the game’s world, instead of pushing Tex forward and backwards with mouse movements, you control Tex like in most First Person games, with the WSAD keys, which is a great improvement, although i would have given the choice to custom map those keys for a better UX, personally i would have even set the middle mouse button as a move forward trigger, the less i need to use the keyboard the better.Another thing i missed from previous Tex games was crouching and stretching, simply because it made it easier to search inside drawers and cabinets and i also liked it when items could have been placed on the inside bottom side of a table, so you need to crouch and look up to see it, it adds another dimension to the game.FMV:Full Motion Video, This is a big part of the game, each time you meet a character you will see an introduction movie, then you will have a branching narrative that evolves the story-line and effects the path and outcome of the game.Then you can interrogate the characters, ask them about other characters and get more information and clues that will help you move forward in the game.The FMV in Tesla Effect is done very nicely in a stunning 2K resolution and some great acting performances from the old cast and the new, my favorite one besides Tex is and always was rook, look for him in the pawnshop.Another thing i missed from the previous games in Tesla Effect is seeing the characters inside the playing environment and not just in the fmv, as much as it looked cheesy and did not add one bit to the game-play it made the world feel a little more alive.Adventure Puzzle Game:The adventure side of TE is pretty much the same as in the other games, there are 3 things you can do to advance.1. solve inventory puzzles, most of the time the item you need will be close by to where you need to use it, but others will be located far away or even in a different location, this sometimes requires an insane amount of pixel hunting, but that was always a part of it.You will also need to combine certain items to advance.2. The dialogues, ask the right character the right question or basically make sure you talk with everyone about everything, even if it’s not required to advance, the dialogues are the most fun part of the game, so don’t skip any.Another little thing that bugged me in the game was when i got stuck because a previous unavailable location became available and i had no idea that this location was even a part of the game, it was one of the rooms in the hotel, i would have give the player some indication that this location will be a part of the game later on, even if the character just scream at you through the door “Come back later, i can’t talk right now”, i would know i should try it again every time i get stuck (for those of you who played the game i am talking about Saffyre).3. the puzzles in TE are not easy by today’s standard, but are easier and somewhat plainer than in the previous installments, I remember getting stuck on the Mayan calendar puzzle in Pandora Directive for over a week, but solving it was 7 times more satisfying and rewarding, i acknowledge that most gamer today do not have the patience for this type of puzzles and i believe that’s why they were dumb down, but this was not a deal breaker for me and i enjoyed the puzzles nevertheless.There was a small issue that bothered me with some of the puzzle, the camera view was way too far and it was hard to see what’s going on in the puzzle, this happened in about 3-4 puzzles in the game.4. the graphics, there was and still is a lot of chatter around the graphics and 3D models used in TE, the graphics are 10 time better than the previous games and that is obviously expected, but they are a little dated, which may draw back some of today gamers, i personally enjoyed the art and it didn’t bothered me one bit, so just watch one of the videos online and judge for yourself.In conclusion:As I said in the beginning of this review, I enjoyed playing TE, i got the experience i was looking for, but I think there is room for improvement on future installments.I am looking forward to see how the gaming community will react to this game and hopefully i will get the pleasure of playing a new Tex Murphy game in the near future.For now i’ll settle for a second run through with a different path on Tesla Effect.Time Played: 10-20 hours

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												If you can remember the Tex Murphy games of old (Under a killing moon when I was about 11 or 12, The clowns head in the toxic sludge) You'll certainly adore this one... all Tex's old haunts back in Glorious 3D and a major case to solve.It's good... but...It was done on a budget... Tex needs the hollywood Budget... it's too big a game to pass off for less than a few mill... What they've done is amazing... The FMV's are truely great. Interviewing people for clues is well done... but it needs to be bigger... There should be 3-4 Cases for Tex to be solving... I hope Modding crews get onto it... could be done (Although FMV's wont be usable... maybe freeze frames of the actors?) The low budget shows in the Graphics... although it's not too bad if you played the originals newbies will wtf at the seemingly dated graphics... most painful if you get a glimpse of an NPC. I do understand that the effort was put into the FMV's and storyline. Maybe TM7 will get the publisher backing it needs. The road Tex lives on has been brought to life... it does look good... it's not next gen graphics... certainly does the trick... but it's not as good as it should be for the wonderous game it is. Few other nitpicks about items generally being small and you have to painstakingly examine rooms inch by inch (Certainly on the harder mode where you don't have the flashlight and *Sparkle* effect on items of interest) But it is a long game... first playthough took around 20 hours on hard. Like I say finding items can be a task. But certainly a great deal longer than the 8 hours on the recent COD game... there are also multiple endings and multiple chat paths which is nice. Can't help but think if a couple of mill had been thrown at the game for a decent graphical engine we'd be looking at a Game Of The Year easily. It's all well and good for those who loved the originals and wish to find out what happened to Tex and is a nice bit of closure on one of Gamings underdogs. But it needs more... I hope someone out there reognises this is a niche market that does have a fanbase... there are plenty of mature gmaers who'd eat this up... also there are a whole hoard of younger gamers sick of the 'run here, shoot that, run here, shoot that' games that are released daily. Tex encourages you to use your mind. Aside from that... I'm well glad I have this in my libaray with the other Tex games... they'll easily come out on a wet weekend where I can sit down as NSF's finest PI and crack a case wide open.
