												Got off to a rocky start when I had to wait for a patch to remove audio stuttering and very laggy gameplay, but after that it played wonderfully. The game itself was fantastic and I really enjoyed my time with it. I'm yet another of the Kickstarter backers so I could probably be expected to like the game (and it's pretty obvious the entire thing was aimed at fans of the old games), and everyone's already mentioned the downside of the 3D environment's quality (didn't really bother me until I got up close and personal with the occasionally encountered 3D character models, eurgh), but if you like sardonic quips, unravelling a mystery, and good FMV, you can't go wrong with a bit of Tex.If you haven't played this or any other game from this series before, you might want to start out with the classics, starting with Under a Killing Moon, then Pandora Directive and Overseer, which you can now find here on Steam or on GOG (The first two games, Mean Streets and Martian Memorandum, play somewhat differently to these later three, which introduced and expanded on the winning formula seen in Tesla Effect).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Tex is back and that's a darn good thing!  Everything I enjoyed about the Tex Murphy adventures, the silly and witty puns, the surprisingly deep storylines, the crazy cast of characters and engaging puzzles are all here in the Tesla Effect.  This time, they're wrapped in shiny Ultra HD and the video is SHARP!  There's definitely a tongue-firmly-in-cheek, silly Mystery Science Theater 3000 flair to the sets, costumes and makeup for the filmed scenes - but that's a REALLY good thing!  It feels like you're playing a B movie which is exactly what the Tex Murphy adventures have always been.  To lose that kitchy appeal would completely ruin the experience.Tesla Effect is kind of a love letter to the fans, bringing back a large number of the cast from previous games.  There are a few jokes that won't quite zing if you haven't played the game before, but do not be discouraged if this is your intro to the Tex Murphy canon.  Thanks to some lovely flashbacks, new players can familiarize themselves with the past games' plots and characters.  NOTE: I still encourage anyone to play the previous games because they are wonderful - I actually replayed Under A Killing Moon, Pandora Directive, and Overseer before playing Tesla Effect.  These games have stood the test of time.  Sure, the graphics are dated, but the story, characters, gameplay and puzzles are just as much fun as they were when I first played them years ago.Chris Jones still has me cracking up as the titular character, Tex Murphy, and the rest of the cast is obviously having a ball as well.  The puzzles are overall very good - similar in difficulty and creativity to those from the past games.  There are multiple endings (of which I have only found 2 thus far, but I hear there are at least 4) which are unique and worth replaying the game for.My only minor gripe is that the in-game graphics were only ok.  And that's mainly because so many of the textures were low resolution and some were sloppily applied to the models.  While this didn't detract or deter my enjoyment of the game, I would have liked to have seen a little more care put into the in-game graphics - the same kind of care that was put into the film sequences. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed playing Tesla Effect and I hope that Tex Murphy will be back again soon to again save the world from annihilation.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Several hours into this game and Tex has infiltrated a creepy cult, and been told of an invention that would remove the veil between the living and the dead.  Also, a guy jumped to his death in front of Tex's eyes, right before Tex was propositioned by two entirely separate ladies.In other words, this game put a smile on my face.  If you love stories and characters at all--and don't mind a presentation that at times can feel a little "stripped down" (but charmingly so)--then I can guarantee you'll enjoy this game.  The light humor and noir atmosphere certainly don't hurt either.If you're wondering if you have to already be familiar with the Tex Murphy games to enjoy this, the answer is no.  Take it from me, as I've never played any of them before this one.  In fact, I only have a vague knowledge of what they even were based on hearing them being mentioned so many times on adventure game forums.  (I also once downloaded and listened to the humorous "Tex Murphy Radio theater" based on these characters.)I was aware of the Kickstarter campaign that got this game made, however.  And I find it miraculous that for such a low budget, they were able to produce this polished an experience.  (The team must be friends with a lot of people in the industry.)  No, it does not look like a "real" movie.  It's not quite that cinematic.  But coming from someone whose previous experiences with FMV (Full Motion Video) games included Gabriel Knight 2 and Phantasmagoria, this has to be just about the most polished FMV game ever made.  This may be damning with faint praise, but you can easily find clips and stills of the game in action on the net and decide for yourself if the "FMV" look is something you can enjoy.Special mention has to be made about the music though.  I said before that the look of the game wasn't quite on par with a "real" movie.  Well, the same can't be said for the music.  It's fantastic, and would easily fit in with any high-budget mainstream film.I do also want to make special note of the acting.  I see some people have called it "cheesy" or bad.  I could not disagree more.  Most everyone in the cast is very good, and any "cheesiness" seems to be ithrough intentional over the top hamming it up--all in good fun.  I think if at times it comes off as a bit amateur it is through no fault of the actors themselves.  Basically, this was shot in a very "matter of fact" way with HD cameras that don't entirely convey a purely cinematic look.  Add to that, for the "interrogation scenes" the actors have been instructed to stand dead center in front of the camera and looking directly into the lens the entire time.  It's really hard to come across as natural under such circumstances.  The fact that they largely manage to do so is a credit to them.Anyway, if you're a fan of the adventure genre--specifically because you're a fan of story and character--then you should give this a whirl.***I do have a few criticisms, though.  In no way do they make the game unworthy of purchase, but just know that they're there:  I wish that the streets you navigate through had been populated by some NPCs so as to create a more alive feel to the world.It should also be noted that the latter stages of the game are not as much fun as the first half.  Other reviews have mentioned the unfortunate presence of "pixel hunting" in this game.  While that's true, let me just clarify what that term means in Tesla Effect.  In the old days of adventure gaming, pixel hunting meant that one had to move their mouse all over the screen and click on just the right spot for the game to recognize they'd clicked on the correct object.  That's not quite what it means in the case of Tesla.There aren't truly any areas of the screen to confuse the player as to its "clickability."  Nor are there any objects so small that one can't precisely place their mouse over it.  (After all, when Tex turns his flashlight on, any such objects that tex needs to interact with immediately sparkle.)  What IS an issue however is that the latter half of the game is largely taken up with First-Person Doom like navigating around some real-time environments while Tex/you must find different objects, push buttons, etc.  I know most people wouldn't find such gameplay an issue.  In fact, first person, Blair Witch-like experiences are (unfortuantely) what most gamers have come to think of when you say "video game" to them.  For a lot of people, videogames are nothing BUT that.However, that's not the kind of experience I treasure in a game.  I enjoy games (particularly Adventure games) for the characters and story--elements that Tesla Effect has in spades at the beginning, but which gradually dissipate as the game goes on.  Unfortunately, as the player wanders around these vast, sterile 3D environments (the multi-floored "Tesla Society" building being the worst, in that it never ends), much of that sense of character and story is lost.  Yes, sometimes you'll hear Tex's voiceover comment on something when you encounter a locked door or whatever, but it's not enough to remove the sense that, yup, you're currently playing a game similar to 99% of games that people play these days.The cut-scenes and sense of story do return at the end, thankfully.  However, it's not until after the player has slogged their way through a lot of tedium.

												I played two previous Tex Murphy adventures when I was younger: Killing Moon and Pandora Directive.  This new game is better than both of them.  It still features most of the original cast that you know and love but vastly improves on the control interface.  Gone is that clunky old "push the mouse button to move, use the arrow keys to look up and down" interface.  It's now a streamlined WASD movement configuration that everyone is used to by now.  It still has the great puzzles and sense of humor.  I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												I have to say that Tesla Effect turned out to be a lot better than I had imagined. The good things that made the old 90's games so enjoyable were still there: the gloomy, post-apocalyptic sci-fi setting, the tounge-in-cheek-film noir/detective investigative style, the wonderfully sleazy jazz soundtrack, and the cheesy, daytime soap-/b-level class acting. I was even pleasantly surprised that the graphics were as good as they were, with overall really nicely rendered 3D, even if worked a lot better with the environments/bakgrounds than anything that was supposed to resemble people.Still, Tesla Effect is by no means any masterpiece - for a game that took a lot of the great things from the original franchise and tweaked, improved and polished it, there was a surprising amount of things left in that you figured would have been removed. Just like previous games, there are a lot of rather frustrating and tedious logic puzzles that break the mood of the story by not really feeling like they are connected to anything in the games story, apart from being an excuse to throw in slider puzzles to lengthen the gameplay. But then again, those have always has been present in the Tex Murphy games, so I suppose it's not too surprising, but Tesla Effect definately seems to have A LOT more of them than previous games. (And yes, there even is a kind of a short maze puzzle. Not an old-school-bad maze, but still.) I would definately have liked more of the inventory- and investigative puzzles.However, the absolute worst thing is probably the extremely annoying bug that seems to be a common problem for a lot of people, where the audio/graphics of the game stutter and lag to point of almost making the game unplayable at times. That did remove quite a lot of the enjoyment from the game, and hopefully it's something that will be patched/fixed in the future.So, in the end, would I recommend Tesla Effect? Well, yes. If you played any of the earlier games and liked them: absolutely.  Tesla Effect captures the exact same feeling and mood that made both Under a Killing Moon and The Pandora Directive thourougly enjoyable. Story-wise, it's a nice and interesting plot that tries to tie together a lot of loose threads, and partly succeeds, even though it doesn't carry quite the same weight of conspiracy and thrill of it's predecessors. You might enjoy it even if you haven't played the previous ones and just like post-apocalyptic sci-fi/film noir, but I think a lot of the charm does come from its association with the previous games. An enjoyable, if not perfect return from San Francisco's most bumbling gum-shoe.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I wasted many hours of my youth in the 90's playing the Tex Murphy Adventures and it's great to see it back without being changed, updated, adjusted or mutilated for todays modern audience. It doesn't need it! It’s great to see a classic style game brought to life with the same love, care and attention that was given to the originals. From the funny, over the top but brilliant acting in the FMV scenes, to the vivid albeit dated graphics and interesting story, the game is a work of art. The story, while perhaps not quite upto the standards of previous adventures, is fun and keeps you interested throughout. Fantastic game. Other developers should take note and could learn a lot from this! Buy it now!Pros+Tex is back!!!+Great to see an old series brought back to life in the same spirit as previously without ruining it+Brilliant acting+HD FMV+In places it’s hilarious +Interesting and challenging puzzles+Decent story+Good sound and music+Runs great with few bugs - uses the Unity EngineCons-Interface is not the greatest-Graphics are dated (though this is not really a down side and has no negative impact in the game, they just could have been a bit better)

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I've never played any point and click adventure games before. Never really saw the attraction. But, this game definately shows some of the best of what that genre must have to offer. A slick satire of the entire genre, packed with references to it's root, and modern pop culture, you play as a walking, talking parody  of the Film Noir Grizzled Detective trope in a Shadowrun-esque 2050, filled with mutants, radiation, and a story that seems way to intense for the shlock the game revels in for the first half of the game, but, after a harrowing, almost horror-esque section at the end of the second act, it hits it's tone nicely. If you like point and click adventure games, this is probably going to be quite the fun ride.Like playing Fallout New Vegas on wakcy wasteland, but wish there was less shooting, and more interacting with NPCs? You've struck gold.Just looking for a fun way to spend an evening or two? You could do worse. Much, much worse.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												There is a lot of emphasis on the "full motion video" part, but in the end, it's a point & click adventure in a 3D engine. The 3D environments could be better, though -- but the cutscenes are what you'll be hoping for anyway. And while it's not an hundreds of million dollars movie production, they are quite nice.Tex also doesn't get boring when examining stuff, unless you count the repeats when clicking on the same kind of item in the same environment and get the same comment again.The gameplay isn't too bad. I wasn't a big fan of some areas, when they put a timer on things or made you sneak around stealthy, but it could be worse. Playing in "casual" mode lets you skip some puzzles if you want to -- it will cost you some points, just like getting yourself killed does, but points don't matter anyway.Likewise, there's supposed to be multiple endings, but I doubt they are THAT different. You'll complete the objective, so what? Options in dialogues are usually vague, so you never know what you're saying or where you're heading; I just randomly clicked an answer. I still liked the game -- again, not much of a difference compared to a game where the outcome is fixed anyway.

												HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.One on its kind.  Adventure game with real 3D scenarios and, where all dialogs with characters and all cinematics are videos, like in a series B film. The atmosphear of the videos is somewhat similar to Doctor Who and that kind of TV series with that odd series B look.Story line is strong, deep and interesting enough. Typical anti-hero detectivesque atmosphear but, full of humor, as well.Puzzles aren't mostly that hard and, usually easy to figure out (except very few). Things to do are so variate that you don't go easily bored.It takes a little while to understand games mechanics, since your character wakes up with no memories and, in a world where you can freely move. The tips come when you interact with characters and, your memory gaps start to be filled in.3D graphics aren't spectacular but, serve to the purpose.Voice acting is good and actors do a good job.Translation is a tad defective, at least, in Spanish. This can confuse you about tips and clues. Bad translated words or sentences can lead you to a dead end.Well, this game greatefuly surprised me!. Even that it got lot of topics, it's good enough.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I just beat the game and quite enjoyed it. It's certainly something different from conventional games, both in terms of gameplay and its awesome FMV storytelling. The narrative was well-written and the characters were well-played. Sometimes the gameplay got a little frustrating when looking for something for a long time, but you can always get a hint when you need one. The music was great near the end but slightly lacking in the earlier parts. My main complaint with the game is how its graphics feel like they're from around 2006 when the game was made in 2014. Things are very low-poly and the texture resolution is pretty bad. As a result, the worlds felt much less immersive and engaging than they could have. I felt more time should have been put into the level art. The backgrounds of the FMV scenes were also from the in-game scenes so they were also lacking in visual fidelity except at the ending which was pre-rendered out-of-engine (and, as such, was quite awesome!) Due to the graphics and slightly slow gameplay, I would give this a 7/10 rating. It wasn't fantastic because it felt rather lifeless during the gameplay portions but it was still a very enjoyable story with some pretty unique FMV which is uncommon in gaming!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												At last, what seemed impossible after all these years, becomes a reality....a new tex murphy adventure!The best thing about this series always was the characters, the way they are played by real actors with fmv technology. It doesn't matter how good 3d graphics are , because to be able to watch a character being played by real human being it gives something to the player that it is impossible to emulate with computers. All this depends on the actor's interpretation and how good he is or she is of course.The story, interestingly enough, has good potential...being about Nicola Tesla, his revolutionary creations,  but...finally...it is a total waste. The story wich begins very very well, goes nowhere, and besides that, the narrative it is a total mess by the second half of the game. Really sad because there was some good beginnings there. Technically.... the game is 50 / 50. The fmv (video) parts are great, they are filmed with a 4k digital camera and they had a pretty good post production work. Not so much the production part, wich alltough it has great work done with the green screen and the actors, it has, from time to time, some basic image errors, like complete out of focus sequences, bad editing, weird cuts, and bad compositing (some sequences doesn't make too much sense, the character says something you should know, but in fact you don't , because you didn't play that part. And for a game that plays with choices and interactive fiction, that's a big mistake sadly. Even then....if you played a previous tex murphy game (the last one was from 1998....) you can clearly see the advancements in video technology and what it can be done today, and that's a great thing. Mixing real actors with computer graphics has come a long way.The 3d graphics on the other hand.... they are pretty bad, mediocre at best, even taking into consideration that they are done by a small team with little budget to spend, they could have done better even with this budget. Maybe they should have hired some people for making the 3d graphics part, because it has proven in many games that camed out recently, that you can do much better than this, even with low budget...you just have to know your limitations and hire someone who can make good use of the available tools.Finally, this is and adventure for people that played tex murphy adventures in the past, and wants to have some closure to the characters they knew from the 90s, reuniting one more last time. A bitersweet ending.To newcomers maybe you should pass.UPDATE 24/03/2016 :Finally after playing many adventure gamers from 2014, i have to say my opinion for tesla effect changed drastically. I still am happy to have played one more time with tex murphy, and to be able to put and end to his story. I am happy also to see what can be done with fmv in 2014, it is great. But the adventure has many problems , beginning with the story, the story has potential,begins interesting enough, but goes nowhere, and it is a mess of a narrative by the second half. There are some parts of the story that are necesary to understand what is hapenning and they are blocked from the player in certain paths. So you are playing , tex suddenly starts saying something HE knows, but you don't and the player gets totally lost. Then the story itself becomes completely ridiculous with all that happens after the first half....the guy dressed as the phantom of the opera, the 2 girls throwing themselves at tex (we are a little old for those games right?) the egyptian temple of the followers of tesla, wich works as a military base (???) the 3d graphics are horrible, it's not excuse to have low budget, better things can be done with it, you just need the right people to do it. As they are, the graphics for this game seem made in the 90s... And to be honest, when i played tex murphy games in the 90s, they not only had great FMV , but also great 3d graphics for that time. Those  games were pretty advanced, in all regards. I m sad to say this but Tesla effect is not that.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
OverviewIt’s like going back in time. To 1994, to be exact, when Tex Murphy: Under a Killing Moon came out. It was a live-action, point-and-click adventure game, with bad acting, cheesy special effects, but a story that was pretty interesting and gameplay that backed it up nicely.Want the TL:DR?A great throwback to two decades ago, with an interesting story, and the same cheesy special effects and acting. It’s brought down by blurry graphics and a multitude of clipping issues, and is overly short. Play it in Gamer mode, not Casual, for the best experience.The Good+ Story. Like the previous games, the story is what makes this game. It’s humorous, serious, and at times, weird and offputting. But that’s the draw. There is lots to take in, from the required story portions to the optional questions you can ask pretty much anybody, all in typically cheese FMV.+ Acting. The acting is cheesy, and not the greatest, but it beats the previous games. Tex really is a character you’ll want to hate.+ Puzzles. Some of the puzzles are odd, but most wind up fitting nicely into the theme of the game. However, they’re all pretty easy, and you shouldn’t have any issues whatsoever with any of them.The Bad- Clipping. My word, the clipping is atrocious. You’ll clearly clip through windows, doors, gates and holes. It’s as if the dev’s didn’t even try to add collision detection. The worst is when you clip through a wall you clearly should be ducking under, but can’t because there’s no duck option, yet when you watch the subsequent cutscene, the people duck under through. It’s odd.- Poor graphics. Very poor graphics. Walls and backgrounds are blurry, the flashlight looks weird. A non-static point-and-click game doesn’t need to have the fanciest of graphics, but these are just bad.- Very short. The game can be completed in a couple of hours, and if you play on Casual mode, every object that is of importance sparkles for you when you shine the flashlight over it. Playing in Gamer mode removes the sparkle, as well as stops you from asking for hints, but it’s still over very quick.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												As someone who grew up playing computer games in the 90s, Tesla Effect offers a fantastic return to an era when the capabilities of the computers of the day were pushed beyond their boundaries with spectacular results. While Tesla Effect won't tax any modern computer, it still offers a compelling game with good graphics, which will hopefully stand the test of time.I'm a diehard Tex Murphy Fan. When I first started the series with Under a Killing Moon and its four CDs under DOS, I was instantly hooked. Having played the games that followed, I was always keen for more, so when Microsoft bought Access and effectively killed Tex Murphy, especially after the cliff-hanger that ended Overseer, I was devastated. Thankfully, due to a successful Kickstarter campaign, we now have a conclusion to that story, with spectacular results.Tesla Effect continues the same formula as its preceding games, which is actually not a bad thing. If you've ever played Under a Killing Moon, Pandora Directive or Overseer, then you know what you're getting into. In terms of gameplay mechanics, Tesla Effect benefits greatly from being produced in the modern era, with fantastic graphics and a solid control system in place that's a massive improvement from the clunky controls (relatively speaking) of the prior games.Tesla Effect continues the trend of Full Motion Video (FMV) embedded within a digital game world the franchise was famous for, which offers a great experience. While most games these days tend to use digital models for people, Tesla Effect, and its preceding games, capture real actors and place them within their digital environments. This provides for (IMO) a much better story delivery method, which has always been used to great effect in the Tex franchise.While the game can be played stand-alone, it's probably better if you jump back to Overseer as its story bleeds into Tesla Effect's to a degree. There's plenty of homage to the franchise, which should bring great excitement to fans (Which I certainly loved!), but it may not have the same effect on those who've never played the series before.Tesla Effect essentially boils down to a detective adventure game within a 3D world you can explore. It is loaded with lots of puzzles for you to sink your teeth into, as well as a witty story rife with choice. You will be expected to look closely at the environment to find elements to assist you on your quest, which at times can be a little irritating as the items are either obscure, or blend into their environments a little too well, but the reward for correctly identifying, combining and utilising the items is satisfying.All interactions with characters are provided through simple but vague options which you can choose. Importantly, the game is designed such that the choices you make as you interact with the characters have the ability to shape the game's ending, which is nice. Each of the options provides an interesting and often humorous reply from Tex, sometimes leading to your downfall if approached poorly.For fans of the series, all of the key actors are back and this is absolutely fantastic. It's great to see so many actors from the franchise put their hands up to recast their roles after such a long time, which provides great continuation for the series and continues to anchor the game in the franchise's world. The new cast members for this game, such as "The Soup Nazi", also work well, but there are also a few other well known celebrity actors included in the game too, much like in the earlier games.Overall, if you're a Tex Murphy fan, most definitely pick this up. If you've never played Tex Murphy games before, you owe it to yourself to try out what was, in my opinion, one of the greatest gaming franchises of the 90s. If you’ve never played Tex games before, pick up the preceding three games and give these a go too. While their graphics become increasingly dated and ordinary with age, their stories and detective mechanics are what really make them shine, and therefore, still worth pursuing.Tesla Effect: A Tex Murphy Adventure, is a game I most highly recommend!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I've played through all but Overseer of the previous Tex Murphey adventures when they first came out and had varying amounts of nostalgia for them, but I much prefered the later fully FMV entries in the series and Tesla Effect is a really fun conclusion.  Now I have to actually go back and finish my playthrough of Overseer, which I have kicking around somewhere.  But back to Tesla Effect.The best parts of the whole thing are the cast.  A few are soooo bad it's hilarious, most are decent, and a few, especially Tex himself and Rook, are really great.  Lots of laughs.  The humor from the previous games has survived.The story is interesting at first, but about 2/3 of the way in, things start getting weirdly complicated, like four or five people were writing while off on their own and then feeding their plotlines into the final product with only occasional collaboration.  I mean, you could follow what was happening, but it got pretty dumb by the end.  Also, while I very much appreciated the handful of branching choices, I would have liked more contextual clues when they popped up.  On my first playthrough I got one of the odd endings that didn't feel like it really fit the overall story up until that point, because of a single choice I took to be a joke at first.Gameplay is all about picking up everything that is pick-up-able, examining and trying different combinations of items, as well as asking every single person you encounter about every single topic available.  Death traps are situational and sometimes annoyingly cheap (I'm looking at you stealth section and lab exploration).  There is no combat.  It is a point-and-click adventure, afterall.The puzzles range from simple speed bumps a small child could solve, to the occasional head-scratcher needing a bit of trial and error, to the classic adventure game standby of "now what were the devs thinking when they came up with this one", where you have to imagine what would make sense in the immediate context rather than what would work in real life.The FMVs were all very clear and polished, while the rendered art style was classic Tex, and barely updated.  The devs were clearly writing a love letter to the series, the characters and the old school fans.  I had a great few nights running through this with nostalgia goggles on, and will probably do so again after I finish Overseer.  I would highly reccomend this to any fans of the early 90s FMV adventure genre, and it's a must have for anyone wanting to see one last Tex Murphy case.  If you're neither, however, odds are you'd be better off just watching a Let's Play, if only for the cutscenes, because the older style and sensibilities will probably be lost on you.

												Once again, the people behind this series have gone and done another great job of making a classic adventure game into yet ANOTHER classic adventure game.Tesla Effect is another story adventure of the Tex Murphy series. Although just another adventure game, it's not just the adventure game part. It's the "tongue in cheek" humor that, anyone who knows this game well, understands and appreciates.In this game, you are, once again, Tex Murphy, P.I., working on another case. Becuase of the humor it presents, there are MANY jokes and references to many icons, cultures, and even some movies and music. Indiana Jones, 1960's song, even flashbacks of the previous games, are in this adventure game.One thing that has not changed since the beginning is that they have used the same actor for all the Tex Murphy games. Because I have been a big fan of this series, it's great to see some things are not lost and haven't changed. Atlus designed a great game that follows how "Access Software" used to make. Thank you for making a classical game more classical than ever and keeping the original actor for this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												First and foremost, welcome back Tex!!! I have missed you!!  Been 16 years I have been waiting to find out what happened to Tex and Chelsea at the end of Overseer and I never thought I would see another game after Microsoft bought out Access Software and pretty much killed it all. But here we are and those questions have been answered. For any Tex Murphy fan, this is a must have. Is it tough seeing him aged?? Yes. Is this game as groundbreaking as the games he released in the 90's. No. But this game is still a blast.The graphics aren't spetacular, but they are solid and the  cutscenes are excellent. The same Tex wit we were used to then is still present in this game and i found myself laughing throughout the game. And the host of co-start is also present here just like in the all the other games. There are also many items throughout the game that u click that takes you back to the old games and shows you clips from those games as well.This game also brings back many characters from those older games and keeps the nostalgia going, making this feel like old times.Some of the puzzles are quite complicated and there is very little direction as to what you are supposed to do, but eventually, it can be figured out and solved. Most of the puzzles are very cool and the game continues to move at a fairly quick pace. But be sure to search and click on everything you can find because there are several little gems to be found that are absolutely hilarious.When the game ended, there was alot of hope that this would not be the last, and I hope that is the case. There is alot left in the series as far as I am concerned and I hope to enjoy a couple of more games before they call it quits.Thanks Chris Jones and Adrian Carr for keeping Tex alive and please don't give up. there are hardocre fans out there who have been waiting for this and will suppport you as much as we can. .Until then, I have this game, and if you don't have it (especially you Tex fans), get it. Nice price for an excellent challenging game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Tesla Effect is a Tex Murphy game for the fans. If you enjoyed the previous FMV Tex Murphy games, you can buy this game now. Essentially the same basic idea, but witch better FMV. Better yet, the stories will tie all the loose ends together/ If you are not familiar with the Tex Murphy series: it's more or less an interactive movie / adventure game. You need to solve puzzles and collect/use different items to progress. The game has film noir /  comedy / over the top vibe to it, so you must be in to that.  I really liked the humor and the story-line. The game has 5 paths and 5 endings, so there is some replay value. Off course, once you figure the puzzles out, the game will progress much faster. Don't expect hq graphics or blistering action. Your reflexes will not be tested. Just sit back and relax the show, the cut scenes can be very long. Recommended if you want to check out what the FMV-hype was all about or if you like the Tex Murphy series.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												After waiting decades for this sequel, I REALLY wanted to love this game. And then I found I really wanted to at least mildly enjoy it. And then I really just wanted to finish it and get it out of the way to free up my HD.I'm an oldschool fan of the Tex Murphy series, and have played all the previous games multiple times, and still have fond memories of those previous games. But this game was a tragic pig-piling of incredibly vague dialogue choices, badly cliched characterization, lame sexist jokes, and all around a boring story with no mystery.As far as gameplay and puzzles go, it's pretty much what you'd expect from any other point and click. Most of the puzzles were fun, but some where just so obscure and unintuitive in their execution that I often found myself rolling my eyes and sighing more and more.Being a fan of point and click adventure games, and having been an avid Tex Murphy fan, I can't even honsetly recommend this game to other Tex Murphy fans, let alone other adventure gamers. Don't waste your time with this one.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Though the humour is at times cliche and overdone, the story itself is awesome.  There's TONS of cut scenes and video footage to go along with the story.  The puzzles are nice - not too tricky, but not too easy either, and the use of "casual mode" makes it a bit easier to find key items in the game.  I would absolutely recommend this game to anybody looking for a fun adventure game to play.  But please be mindful of your internet bandwidth, as 16 gigs is pretty steep.[Edit]My only *real* gripe about the game is the points system.  It seems that dying takes away A LOT of points.  It could be debated that this adds to the challenge, but I've always been a fan of intentionally doing stupid things in adventure games to see how the programmers went about them.  This means intentionally falling off cliffs etc.  If I could make one suggestion, it would be to make the points system based on finding items, examining things, and solving puzzles; and not have points deducted for dying (or, lessen the blow of lost points during deaths)

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Tesla Effect is a faithful continuation of Tex Murphy’s adventures: Chandler Avenue, goofy humor, convoluted plot, cheesy FMV scenes, action/stealth sequences, piling of seemingly random names and facts in the beginning that gradually start making sense after the middle – it’s all in there.The graphics and FMVs look 2000-ish, although the movie resolution is quite high (and I played on a 3D display that added a bit of 2014-ness to the first-person parts ;-) ). The puzzles are neither too easy nor too difficult. Some objects are hard to find but in casual mode there is a way to highlight them. The acting is hit-and-miss. The music fits well. The UI could be better but both UI and character controls are much more convenient than in the previous games.The games from this series are entertaining in the same way as a good tongue-in-cheek B-movie. I think old fans that loved the previous installments for what they were are likely to enjoy this one. People expecting state-of-the-art graphics and movie-quality acting as given may be disappointed.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												A little disappointed.  While I enjoyed having the chance to revisit my earlier days of Tex Murphy and I did have a few chuckles, it just didn't have the same spark.  Image looked better, but the production value was poor.  Low video quality might have been better for this dated series as the poor makeup quality might not have been as noticeable.  Given the advancements in texturing, the texture quality was quite poor.  The acting reminded me of some high school preformances I had to sit through with a lot of redundant dialog visual descriptions.  I replayed the previous adventures for the different outcomes But will not with this latest installment.  There was nothing new here and I will just watch the alternate endings on youtube. I only paid $5 for it, so I guess it was worth that and play through only took about 16 hours.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												The best word I can use to describe the Tesla Effect is mediocre.  There are some things the game does really well and some things that were disappointing.The look of the game was overall good the cg backgrounds only sometimes clashing with the actors in front of a green screen.  There were some cut scenes that I wish they actually had real sets.The acting was good with the exception of a few characters.Where I take issue with the game is in the story.  Tesla Effect seems to want to ride the rails between serious noir detective story and goofy comedic game which was to its detriment.  One minute Tex has a bad pun and the next there's people getting violently murdered and heavy sexual innuendo.  I would have much prefered the game if they picked one direction and stuck with it.The gameplay is in the very traditional adventure game style of: use x on y and combine x with z, so if you like that it's fine.The puzzles with one exception were well done (if not a little easy) with the exception of one which requires the player to know of an ancient egyptian puzzle from outside the game to know what the goal of the puzzle is.As a new player to the Tex Murphy series, I found the game to be geared too much towards old players.  Several Items are strewn about the game that if you click on them it plays a clip from an old game.  I think these were supposed to be funny parts from the originals, but without their context i didn't find them funny at all, just stange and confusing.If you are a fan of the series you probably will like it, but if like me you are an adventure gamer new to Tex you'll probably be unimpressed.  Maybe buy it on sale.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Long, long, long time Tex Murphy fan here, one of the ones that was actively pining away for a new Tex after Overseer abruptly ended.  I have to sadly say, that at this time, I am not impressed.  I'll keep it simple...-The first person camera is poorly done, and leaves me with severe sea sickness like queezy feeling, even for hours after I save and close down the game session. (fiddling with the field of view in options helps but doesn't completely fix this problem)  I've played First person shooters for years, and I don't have this problem with AAA designed FPS titles that perfect the veiwing angle, which eliminates motion sickness for me-Opening game story/writing is very bad-dialog writing and acting delivery is extremely bad and lacking the charm of the old Tex games.  Tex was never known for great acting, but he was known to pull off bad acting and all sorts of hokiness with a fantastic endearing quality and I'm just not agreeing with it in this new release.-the early game puzzles are really lame (Spoiler' ' an overly complicated and obnoxious game of simon and running all over town without much aim or directive just to find a ladder and have some forced introductions with currently useless new characters who aren't very interesting ' ')-I cannot stand the Mystery Science Theatre sounding PDA voice that is constantly a part of the game, it's the voice of the personal electronic organizer.  I'd rather be alone with Tex's internal monologue and not annoying interuptions of MST voices popping in with awful one liners and insults.I only played through the first hour or so of the game + I finished the entire demo before the final game was released.  I found the demo to be a tad bit better than the intro of the new Tex game, so perhaps the game gets better as it goes on, but with nothing so far that I find endearing or appealing combined with the naseau inducing first person camera implementation, and I don't think I'll be back to find out if I'm missing out or not.Personally I'd rather replay UAKM or Pandora Directive or go replay Myst III, IV and V than try this again anytime soon.Sorry Tex, I still love ya, but please, try again.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Warning: I have no nostalgia for older titles in this genre. I did not complete the game for reasons which are clarified below.What the game got right:This game is very cheesy. The cutscenes and character interactions, the one-liners from the PI you play as -- those are the strong points of this game. The FMV parts of the game are really well done: the resolution doesn't make you feel sick, the green screen is just viewable around the edges of the characters but not too distracting. The 2k resolution for the FMV sequences is probably nice for people who have the hardware to display that kind of thing. What it got wrong:However, I would not recommend this game. It just doesn't feel like a game. On top of that, the graphics of the main street you first walk around it sicken me. It feels like Deus Ex. Both games were set in the future, and both games look like they were made in 2000. Deus Ex WAS released in 2000, but Tesla Effect was released in 2014. There's a car I saw on Main street that looked almost exactly like a flattened blackened, car from DE. I know this is a game which is trying to appeal to older folks and older gamers by mimicking older games, but come on. It's hard to go from 1080p FMV sequences to crappy everything else. It's immersion breaking.So, as a game, I would not recommend this. It's like you're swimming in an ocean of outdated graphics and mediocre gameplay, and every FMV sequence is a breath of fresh air before you have to plunge your head back into the ocean to get to the next part so you can breath in the FMV again. Some people say, once you get immersed in the story, the graphics will become insignificant. Maybe. I did not get immersed in the story, and after quitting the game once, had little inclination to go back.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I have a lot of problems with Tesla Effect: A Tex Murphy Adventure, and I really really wish I didn’t. I want to make sure before I spill out all my complaints I make this very clear: games like this need support, dev teams who are willing to take the risk faithfully resurrecting the genres and characters many of us cherish from our childhood should be applauded. No matter how much I dislike this game I think that it was a competent remake of a classic game that has a strong cult following and a lot of loving support. I would be a hypocrite if I condemned this game for being itself simply because I’m not into the content while at the same time begging for developers to bring back Banjo Kazooie.With all my respect for the resurrection of the Full Motion Video (FMV) crime adventure on the table, I thought The Tesla Effect was not very good. Right from the beginning, inspecting objects around the opening area leads to a multitude of (what I presume to be) clips from the original Tex Murphy games. They are abysmally cheesy and for someone who never experience the franchise in the past, they feel like inside jokes that I’m completely left out of. The cheese I can absolutely forgive because the original games were from a very different time culturally and technologically, however the feeling of being left out as a new player is really disheartening. Next up is a very personal and subjective complaint with very little merit in a review of a game like this, but I find FMV cutscenes to be disturbingly unnerving. Every time a cutscene would trigger I was so uncomfortable. I’m not sure if it’s the clash of real people against digital backdrops or if it’s just that principal of the uncanny valley, either way I just could not stomach that art style. On to a very different issue; I’m not sure how the original game played, but not being able to walk while moving the mouse is absolutely ridiculous. I don’t care if that was part of the “charm” of the original game or not, having to walk forward, stop, look left with the mouse, and then be able to walk forward again is just inexcusable. Finally, I have never had a game run my rigs so hot before. On my brand new laptop (which I frequently use to play games like Space Engineers Civilization BE and Bioshock Infinite) after only 15 minutes of play I was unable to use the keyboard. I typically hit around 40-45C near the GPU but running Tesla Effect caused the majority of my keyboard to hit 50 degrees!I support the developers with all my heart and I think more risks like this need to be taken, but Tesla Effect was just not right. Between personal and mechanical issues, I would not recommend this game to anyone.

												i have mixed feelings about this game, it sort of relies a bit too much on clips from the old tex murphy games and the graphics are pretty outdated, some of the acting is obviously someone reading out their lines from a board and have pretty poor acting skills, now im thinking its sort of on purpose to keep the cheesy feel like previous games, but the poor acting is  a bit over the top from some of the actors ( not tex) . The graphics are rather low in detail and not too inspiring. Puzzles ; ive done some of the puzzles in the game, some of the first puzzles, really really got on my nerve, and is the biggest contributor to me disliking it somewhat, the other parts i sort of could live with, with no big impact, ...puzzle that got to me : the wheel puzzle above the electronics shop ; flashing lights on a wheel in different colors flashing by fast, repeat combination ; seriously... how am i supposed to repeat the last and second line when the flashing of the lights is 8 spots on a wheel... and it flashes 4-5 times a second . Sorry im not rainman...cant memorize that fast.  And secondly its not fun at all! Yes i moved past the puzzle... by using a walkthrough, and still missing the buttons at times... Sound : very spartan ... and alot of sound effects arent even synced up within a second(!) of the spot where it supposed to be there ( read : coit tower elevator) . The story so far aint all that bad, it has some humourous points now and then, but the game so far feels very rushed and unfinished in the finish.  (4 hours of playing), and yes i know this game was crowdfunded, but alot could be saved by some better sound effects and more, . the graphics ..dont know if its an hommage and purposly lofi to reflect under a killing moon, which i frankly remember as having better fitting graphics.Now ill play this game more , and possibly finish it; i dont know if i would recommend it to any yet, but as im somewhat dissapointed in the game so far, id have to say no, as there is no way to rank the game other than yes or no.  Also the game isnt the most stable software out there...well thats my two cents so far.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
"Oh, an anvil. I'm sure it'll come in handy later." (actual game quote)What sinks this game, after all, is its inept game design: 95 percent of the gameplay consists ofA) tedious, sometimes frustrating pixel-hunting for silly objects that are employed in unprecedentedly obtuse ways: "find all baseball cards to unlock safe" / "clean petri dish to open locker" ..... game is from 2014 but more reminiscent of 1980s text adventures.B) an absurd mishmash of cobbled together logic puzzles, which feel hopelessly tacked-on and completely disrupt any stylistic, thematic, and gameplay cohesion. It's painfully embarrassing when the developers suddenly insert an entire Ancient Egypt section with puzzles like the river crossing problem and probably think this is a great idea.Your role is always confined to abstract, low-level problem solving that has nothing to do with the story itself. The story is neatly told through high quality FMV cutscenes while you are searching for screwdrivers, sausages and nose hair trimmers in low quality 3D environments.Tyrannosaurus Tex. It's one, huge dinosaur of a game with graphics from the early 2000s and gameplay from the early Pleistocene. Like Duke Nukem Forever, this is a game that came out 15 years too late and, maybe, should have never been made in the first place.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Adventure games as a genre may be on life support, but FMV adventure games are dead and buried in an unmarked grave so it's amazing that Tesla Effect exists at all. What's more is that the FMV segments are actually the highlight of the game. Yeah, it's corny and low-budget but it revels in its corny low-budgetness. Chris Jones is great as Tex Murphy and has an innate knack for delivering groan-inducingly bad dialogue in a way that's actually funny and charming.That being said, as an adventure game Tesla Effect is sub-par. The puzzles are dull and aside from a few hard to spot items they're incredibly simple. The 3D environments are ugly as sin and travelling around them is slow and the movement is often buggy. Despite really liking the charm of the FMV segments I couldn't be bothered to finish this one.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
Introduction : Tesla Effect begins in 2050, seven years after Tex and his love interest, Chelsee Bando, were attacked at the end of Tex Murphy: Overseer. The story starts as Tex suddenly awakes disoriented in his office at the Ritz Hotel with strange markings and signs of violence on his body and no memory of the past seven years. He then discovers that Chelsee has been missing ever since the attack and is presumed dead. He sets out to find out what happened to him, what became of Chelsee, and to regain his past memories, and in so doing uncovers a web of intrigue involving murders, double crosses, and the lost inventions of Nikola Tesla.(+)Graphics : Graphics are great , the game can support graphics up to 2K to support live-action sequences .(-)Cutscenes / Story :  I know that most of you won't be agreeing with me , but the cutscenes are boring , acting is really below the charts and story looks nice but its executed terribly . Of course it changes from people to people but to me i don't like too long cutscenes with terrible acting .(+)Gameplay :  You can navigate 3D environments in first-person, search for clues, and use inventory items. The game also includes logic puzzles and a branching conversation system for interviewing characters. Like The Pandora Directive, it features "narrative pathing" where player choices affect the story and endingInteresting story , too long real-life cutscenes with terrible acting . It would have been better as a movie .5/10 -   Triskelion Turbella Reviews

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game wins the award for most frustrating game I've ever played, as well as the award for ugliest in-game aesthetics.I realize the graphics for the gameplay weren't too important, but it looks like they asked some 1st year 3D modelers to do this one for free (source: studied 3D for 1 college session and could do as well or better).As far as frustating gameplay; the entire game is an exercise in trail-and-error puzzling as well as pixel hunting (across the previously mentionned terrible aesthetically unpleasing graphics).  I have never been so annoyed nor gotten as angry at a game in my life, and I've played all the Souls games, among other games that have a tendency to make you lose your cool at some point or another.Some puzzles I thought I had figured out the logic behind, but when solving it didn't work I resorted to trial and error until it worked, and I still don't know the logic behind those puzzles.  I've seen others complete them on Youtube, and it only confused me more when, in 1 instance in particular, they solved a puzzle by doing what I had done.. except for me it didn't work.Puzzle and point-and-click games aren't my favorite genres so if you're a big fan of those you may get a better experience, especially if you're a Tex Murphy fan.On the other hand, I enjoyed the FMVs.. good cheesy fun.  The intro movie was the best part of the game.. got me pumped to be immersed in a movie I'd play in as the main character.. and then I got plopped into the gameplay and I barfed in my mouth a little.TL:DR - Great B-movie, terrible game.

number of helpful: 11 of 33 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												20 years ago FMV was a very new and cool concept in PC gaming.  It promised to bring ultra realism and a whole new level of immeration in gaming.  Unfortunately the games that came out with FMV were less than steller.   One game series that went all in on FMV was the Tex Murphy series of adventure games.  Tex 3, 4, and 5 (Under a killing moon, Pandora, Overseer) all featured this new technology.  The Tex series was an enjoyable if cheezy adventure game series that focused on an out of luck PI who was 2 parts buffon and 1 part saint.  The draw initially was the FMV but the series milked successfuly the humor and puzzle elements for all they were worth.  For the most part the Tex series enjoyed moderate success with gamers but not at the same level of a Monkey Island or a Sierra title.  Now we have yet another Kickstarter romp though an old game series that is long since dead.  Very dead in fact....   Its been 16 years since Overseer left Tex fans on a clifhanger.  As one of those fans I have to admit I was excited at the prospect of seeing the old Tex in action again and finally geting a proper send off for a beloved series.  Its painful for me to admit but I REALLY wanted to see another game in this series.  Enough for me to fork over 100 bucks 2 years before it was released. In this case I think it might have been better to have Tex stay dead.   While the game industry has moved on its clear the designers either havent or thought they had to stick to the old forumla because TeslaEffect is basicly a slight upgrade from their last outing.  The backgrounds are so pixulated that I think I am back playing in 1997.   Some of the actors are either not professionals or just mailing in their performances (similar to what we saw in UAKM).   The puzzles seem random and dont tie into the world and its story.  When playing as tex and choosing from a text bubble the options are so random it really doesnt matter what option you choose or to even bother to read them.  Clearly the skills of the storytelling and game design for these folks havent advanced a day from the late 90'sThe story itself is corny (what you would expect from the series) and at times hard to follow.  There are many many gems hidden for Tex fans to reminace about the past.   Its mostly overdone and in poor quality, which leaves this Tex fan disapointed.  As of this date (May 2014) there are many bugs still in the game, most are of the audio nature.  The game can get offsync with the audio and at times the audio will cut completely out for a few seconds.  Bottom line is that if you really really really must see a new tex game its probably worth it to you to spend the 15-20 bucks for the cost.  The other 99.999999% of the population however should stay away.   Literally this game is made for about 20-30 indiviudals who stayed true and talked tex in message boards (Unoffical Tex Murphy) all these years.  Me I thank Tex for the fun we had in the 90's but to me he died in that speeder in Overseer.  Happy trails Tex

												A bad effort.Some of the puzzles don't make sense, like I have to ask a guy about a ladder in order for a hotel to open, there is no logic there it's just forcing me to engage in some useless dialog with someone that I had to look up a walk through to find out. The areas are too big and you can spend a lot of time wandering around. It also keeps going back to some dated footage from the previous game. The odd clip might give some veterans of the series nostalgia but for me it's just anoying.  Given the ammount of money and hype around this game you'd expect it to be at least equal with some of the other adventure titles out there like technobabelon or gemini rue. Blah... I don't know if I'll finish this game, but if I do I want be loosing sleep about using walkthroughs to get through it a bit quicker.

number of helpful: 20 of 54 people (37%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Pros:- beautiful full motion video sequences shot in high definition- good acting- first Tex Murphy adventure in 15 years- interesting story- humor- branching pathsCons:- story is hard to get into if you haven't played the previous Tex games- would have been better as a movie than as a game- horrible 3D graphics full of low-poly models and bad textures, game looks like it was made in 2001- bad sound design in 3D environments- uninspired and rehashed puzzles, including lots of kindergarten-level math- a lot of pixelhunting, tiny objects placed in locations you'd never look in- glitchy saving system that may wipe your progress- keys are not rebindable- no controller support- highly unstable framerate dispite low graphical fidelity, even on high-end systems- more of the same, because the game is dedicated to a small nostalgia-blinded fanbaseVerdict:Tesla Effect is designed for Kickstarter backers and that is its biggest flaw. It succeeds at catering to an existing fanbase, but falls flat on its face when trying to be a modern point-and-click. It's not going to win any new hearts and minds. Almost all other PnC adventures released in the past 5-6 years as part of a revival of the genre outshine this game in every aspect. If Tesla Effect does anything well, it's showing that movies should remain movies and games should remain games. Good game design and artistic vision is more important than fanservice.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This games too cheesey to recogmend. If you are afan of the old games you may get a certain feeling of nastalgia from playing it. Having not played any of them beyond a demo for under a killing moon i cant comment to the accuracy to the old style.  Regardless, the world which you walk around in is graphicly below par for a game made this side of 2000. I realise this game was funded through crowd funding, but this doesn't excuse the old textures and graphic models used, not a slap dash approach to CGI rendered animations. Accepting that a substantial amount of the budget did go into making the cinematic cut scenes doesn't excuse them from being lazy elsewhere. The story though did have a certain amount of charm, even if it lacked in the complexity i normally enjoy. The puzzles for the most part were easy to solve and weren't really much of a challenge. The only exception being one which required you to have looked at something a lot more carefully then i did. Several were confusing only in the lack of instructions. Show me what appeared to be a drafts bored and then i find its actually a puzzle where i cant have more then 1 of each tile on each row. Solution was easy once i realised my goal. In some ways this is a hall mark of the style and not really something you can hold against the game, though it is nice when the items aren't limited to only one use. The cheeseyness of the acting though either makes or breaks this game...you will either love it for it, or you will find it distracting from the story telling. For me it was somewhat distracting, i could see what they were trying to do, but the actors just didn't feel up to it. To me it felt like they were overacting. The world felt empty, apart from a few roaming insta killers, there was no real interaction with anyone outside of their preset boxes. When it came up i had considered supporting the kickstarter. Having now played the game, i'm really glad i didn't.

												It starts out fascinating and wonderful. Then it degrades into a series of IQ test sliding tile and number puzzles. Completely arbitrary and disjointed. It's a like a nickelodeon movie where you have to insert a puzzle coin to watch the next 5 minutes.Utterly disappointing and very lazily designed. It's a real shame since the writing and cinematography are great. I laughed out loud many, many times. Remnants of a great series but not quite enough substance to hold it all together.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												I'm a newcomer to this series and  had never before played any Tex Murphy adventure. I got it in a bundle. At first, this appeared to be a rather cheap adventure-style game with some kind of retro charm. However, as I went along with playing it, I started to enjoy the story and the cheesy characters.Gameplay-wise I found myself stuck several times with absolutely no clue how to progess. The searching and trying very quickly felt combersome and frustrating. While it *is* in the spirit of the adventure games of old, today I don't find the time anymore to come back and do the chores of what feels like hours of searching. Also, I had to use a walkthrough in a couple of places to proceed, only to find out that I either would never had realized the solution on my own (too confusing) or that I had all the right ideas but the game expected a very specific sequence of progression (which should be more open to similar solutions).All in all, I recommend this game, although I happened upon it as a free extra in a bundle. I very much doubt that I would have bought it on Steam or elsewhere. Then again, this is a game with a main audience of longtime Text Murphy fans for whom this game is obviously created. Throughout the game, I always felt a bit excluded, like standing on the sidelines and not getting all the jokes. I then turned that into archaelogical curiosity, exploring the pieces of a culture remembering itself. That was kind of special.Now that I know Tex Murphy exists, I would play a followup game. But then again, it felt lacking a little too much polish to be sold for 20 €.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Of note : I only recommend this game for the people who loved the old point&click adventures of the 1990s.This game has a lot to love for the old farts of us who played the old P&Cs.  The same branching dialogues, the same silly puzzles that usually aren't difficult, and the same questionable logic which determines which random objects go together to make functional objects to solve problems.Pros:~ The 4K camera work looks great.  The quality of the FMV portions look fantastic.~ Cheezy dialogue and acting.  It's a YMMV thing, but I love it.~ For those who have followed Tex through his recent adventures in the Pandora Directive and the Tex Murphy Radio Saga, it attempts to tie up all the loose ends and explain what has all happened.  It's a pretty well written story.~ Multiple endings based on dialogue decisions, and while some are better than others, Sapphyre's is great.~ The game is legitimately funny.~ All digital, so NO DISC SWAPPING HALLELUJAH! ~ Tons of references to the earlier games, especially Under a Killing Moon.Cons:~ The puzzles aren't really as difficult as you would think.  And the game follows a fairly predictable thread of 1.) Talk to people on the street 2.) Find items needed to get into a place  3.) Find items in place, and solve puzzles, 4.) Rinse, Lather, Repeat.~ The camera work is great, but the in game 3D world looks like it came right out of 2003, in a not good way.  The world is much more open than previous games, and there aren't the frequent, epic length loading screens, or disc swapping THANK GOD.~ If you didn't play the earlier Tex Murphy games, especially Overseer and Pandora Directive, it may be difficult to grasp the story.  Under A Killing Moon is suggested, because it's the best, but doesn't contribute as much to the story.Ultimately, if you're an oldschool Tex Murphy player, a fan of Point & Click games, interactive movies, or like comedies with a film noir setting, you may love this game.  If you're not into those, you could probably pass on it.

												finished the game in 20/22h. it's been so cool to see tex murhpy's adventures again.no bugs encoutered exept sound lvl problem during FPS sessions.my prefered one was under a killing moon.because of the translation and the text speed i may didn't understand everything in the story.videos are in well hd quality.it's a small budget developpment game so don't ask too much for this game. i congrats all the developpment team, actors and everyone who participated on that game. they worked well to produce another great tex murphy video game.puzzles are ok, sometimes it's been difficult to understand what to do. the helping process in the game was a good idea.aspects to improve at my eyes, for a next game should be :_a better lvl design, art design and game engine. so more interactive stages._more romance and femme fatal/ pin ups appearance during stories_more musics_a option to read again dialogues. they pass one time. so if you missed a information, you can't get it again. specialy when english isn't you mother'language.PS: i encoutered big sound lvl problem during the game. tex voices during FPS parts are so low lvl instead eveything else. even at the minimum lvl et voice at the maximum.hope to see a next adventure !
